question.para: Further to the answer of the Minister for Finance and Administration to part (2) of question No. 2436 (Hansard, 4 June 2001, page 27231) and his reply to part (2) of question No. 2307 (Hansard, 23 May 2001, page 26958), (a) has the number of houses now requiring insulation from increased aircraft noise resulting from management changes increased the number of noise insulation project eligible households and (b) was the environmental assessment of 1995 for the second Sydney Airport wholly defective in light of the two-site selection of Badgerys Creek and Holsworthy.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (a) No.

(b) No. The environmental studies commenced in 1995 led to the announcement in January 1996 that an Environmental Impact Statement would be carried out into the proposed airport development at Badgerys Creek.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 13 February 2002:

question.para: (1) Further to the answer to part (1) of question No. 2414 (Hansard,17 September 2001, page 30802), will the re-opening of the East-West Runway and the commissioning of the Sydney West Airport Environmental Impact Statement (EIS) alone fulfil the Coalition's promise that Sydney Airport would not be sold until that airport's aircraft noise problems had been solved.
(2) Have these two actions alone solved Sydney Airport's aircraft noise problems.

(3) Has the commissioning of the Second Sydney Airport EIS, together with the Coalition's 1996 Aviation Policy, created a legitimate expectation in the minds of the community that Sydney West Airport would be built as part of the solution to Sydney Airport's Aircraft Noise problems; if not, what purpose does the Second Sydney Airport EIS serve in its relation to the Coalition Policy to solve Sydney Airport's aircraft noise problems.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1)-(3) The Government has introduced several measures to mitigate aircraft noise. The Long Term Operating Plan (LTOP) introduced a regime of noise sharing. The Plan introduced significant reductions in noise exposure for those areas most heavily impacted under Labor's noise concentration regime.
The Sydney Airport Curfew Act 1995 provides for the restriction of landings and take-offs only to specific types of aircraft over Botany Bay between 11pm and 6am.
The Sydney Airport Demand Management Act 1997 which came into effect in November 1997 limits the number of planned runway movements to 80 per hour.

After lengthy and careful consideration to finding the best way to cater for Sydney's future aviation needs, the Government concluded that Sydney Airport will be able to handle the air traffic demand over the next ten years and that Bankstown Airport will be made available as an overflow airport for Sydney that will, over time, become an attractive alternative for some airline services.
The Government will further review Sydney's airport needs in 2005.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 13 February 2002:

question.para: (1) Has the aircraft noise enquiry line for Sydney Airport been recently changed from 1800 802 584 to a toll fee national number 1300 302 240: if so, when did this change occur and what is the cost of a call to this number.
(2) Was the 1800 802 584 telephone number a toll free, seven days per week service, operating from 6 a.m. to 10 p.m.
(3) Does the new 1300 302 240 number operate from 6.30 a.m. to 5 p.m. Monday to Saturdays only; if not, what are the operating times of the new number.
(4) Why do people now have to pay to complain about aircraft noise associated with Sydney Airport.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The 1800 802 584 toll free number was changed to local call cost number 1300 302 240 on the 18 of October 2001.
(2) Yes.
(3) Yes.

(4) The free call 1800 number has been replaced by a local call 1300 number because it has become apparent in recent times that a small number of persons have been abusing the free call facility by lodging hundreds of calls each month. Other members of the public have objected to this behaviour as they believe it can give a distorted picture of how the noise is actually distributed between the suburbs.

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 13 February 2002:

quote.para: Do the terms of reference for the HIH Royal Commission cover (a) the HIH policy of underpricing their insurance premiums against the premiums of their competitors and its contribution to the HIH collapse, (b) the HIH practice of under-provisioning for their policyholders claims and its contribution to the HIH collapse, (c) the HIH policy of litigating claims where claimants did not accept the HIH standard offer of 40% settlement and its contribution to the practice of under-provisioning for policyholders claims, (d) the role of the HIH Board committees in the corporate governance of HIH and of their contribution, by negligence or otherwise, to the collapse of the company, (e) the role of HIH senior management in the corporate governance of HIH and of their contribution, by negligence or otherwise, to the collapse of the company, (f) the role of HIH internal and external auditors in assessing whether the policies of HIH in relation to the pricing of its policies and its provisioning for claims were adequate for on-going solvency of HIH and in the best interests of policyholders, (g) the role of the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority (APRA) in assessing whether the policies of HIH in relation to the pricing of its policies and its provisioning for claims were adequate for the on-going solvency of HIH and in the best interests of policyholders and the insurance industry generally and (h) a future role for APRA in determining the minimum actuarial standards for the level of provisioning by insurance companies to meet claims for each class of insurance.

talker.name: Howard, John, MP
Mr Howard
talker.role: Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: The terms of reference for the HIH Royal Commission are broad and direct the Royal Commissioner to inquire into `the reasons for and the circumstances surrounding the failure of HIH'. The terms of reference also direct the Commissioner to inquire into a number of particular matters, including:

(i) whether, and if so the extent to which, decisions or actions of HIH, or any of its directors, officers, employees, auditors, actuaries, advisers, agents, or of any other person contributed to the failure of HIH or undesirable corporate governance practices;
(ii) the appropriateness of the manner in which powers were exercised and responsibilities and obligations were discharged under Commonwealth laws;
(iii) the adequacy and appropriateness of arrangements for the regulation and prudential supervision of general insurance.

The conduct of the Royal Commission is independent of the government. It is a matter for the Royal Commissioner to determine whether particular matters are covered by the terms of reference and warrant investigation.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 13 February 2002:

quote.para: Will he [the Treasurer] introduce legislation to require superannuation funds to fully disclose on the annual superannuation statements forwarded to members the total fees, charges and commissions paid to funds managers and consultants; if so, when; if not, why not.

talker.name: Costello, Peter, MP
Mr Costello
talker.role: Treasurer

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: A number of reforms related to disclosure of fees and charges have already been implemented under the Financial Services Reform Act 2001 (the Act). The Act requires disclosure of fees and charges related to a financial product to occur at a number of stages throughout the life of a financial product.

The legislation includes a requirement for issuers of financial products (including superannuation funds) to disclose amounts paid by holders of financial products in periodic statements. This includes disclosure of fees, charges and commissions paid by a member of the superannuation fund and any deducted from a common fund. Section 1017D of the Act and regulation 7.9.75 of the Corporations Amendment Regulations 2001 (No.4) details these particular requirements.

subdebateinfo.title: Employment: General Employee Entitlements and Redundancy Scheme
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 54)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, upon notice, on 12 February 2002:

quote.para: (1) Did he issue a media release dated 20 September 2001, saying that over 90 per cent of workers who lose their entitlements when their companies become insolvent will receive 100 per cent of their entitlements under the new General Employee Entitlements and Redundancy Scheme (GEERS).

(2) Does GEERS enable the Government to pay advances to terminated employees and later recover those funds in the event of a distribution of assets by the liquidator of the insolvent employer; if not, how does GEERS enable the Government to so recover such funds.

(3) Has his attention been drawn to (a) the insolvency of Traveland Pty Limited on 26 November 2001 and now under administration, (b) the subsequent termination of 550 employees of Traveland on 4 December 2001 and (c) the fact that those 550 former employees had worked the whole of November 2001 without being paid their monthly wages and (d) the fact that, since 4 December 2001, those 550 former employees have received no further payments.

(4) Were the 550 former Traveland employees excluded from the Special Employee Entitlements Scheme for Ansett Group Employees as a result of Traveland's primary assets, including its employee contracts, being sold by the Administrator of the Ansett Group, which included Traveland Pty Limited, on 23 September 2001 to Internova Travel Pty Limited, notwithstanding widespread speculation at the time that Internova Travel did not have sufficient capital to operate a national travel agency network.

talker.name: Abbott, Tony, MP
Mr Abbott
talker.role: Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Yes.
(2) Yes.

(3) (a) Yes. (b) I am advised that approximately 540 employees were terminated from Internova Travel Pty Ltd (trading as Traveland) between 29 November 2001 and 4 December 2001. (c) and (d) The administrator for Internova Travel has advised my Department that some employees have unpaid wages, however, the extent is unconfirmed.

(4) The former employees of Traveland were made redundant as a result of the insolvency of Internova Travel Pty Ltd. Internova Travel Pty Ltd is not an Ansett group company and consequently the former employees are not eligible for assistance under the Special Employee Entitlements Scheme for Ansett group employees (SEESA).

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 13 February 2002:

quote.para: (1) Is he able to say whether gasoline station pumps in California, USA, bear a California Health and Safety Code gasoline health warning label which states “Harmful or fatal if swallowed. Long term exposure to vapor has caused cancer in laboratory animals. Chemicals known to the state to cause cancer, birth defects and other reproductive harm are found in gasoline, crude oil and other petroleum products and their vapor or result from their use. Read and follow label directions and use care when handling all petroleum products.”
(2) Do benzene and 1-3 butadiene precursors occur in higher percentages in Australian unleaded and leaded fuels than in Californian unleaded and leaded fuels.
(3) What percentage of benzene is, on average, in Australian unleaded and leaded petrol and what is the maximum amount of benzene that may occur.
(4) Will he introduce health-warning labels for all Australian petrol bowsers; if not, why not.

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr Kemp
talker.role: Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) I understand that gasoline (petrol) station proprietors in California may use warnings such as this to avoid violation of Section 25249.6 of the Safe Drinking Water and Toxic Enforcement Act of 1986.

(2) In most cases yes. The Californian regulations for gasoline are complex, providing a number of alternative compliance mechanisms. As an indication of average content, flat limits specified by the Reformulated Gasoline Regulations that currently apply to gasoline sold in California are 1% for benzene, 25% for aromatic hydrocarbons and 6% for olefins (all percentages by volume). These components are precursors for emissions of benzene and 1,3-butadiene.

The Australian averages in 1999, according to the latest figures available from the Australian Institute for Petroleum for petrol refined in Australia, were, for benzene: 2.9% for leaded petrol, 2.5% for regular unleaded petrol, and 3.4% for premium unleaded petrol. The average content of aromatics in 1999 in leaded petrol was 23.32% mass, 28.2% in regular unleaded petrol, and 38.7% for premium unleaded petrol (based on reports to the AIP from 6 refineries).

(3) The average benzene content in 1999 was 2.9% for leaded petrol, 2.5% for regular unleaded, and 3.4% for premium unleaded. The Fuel Standard (Petrol) Determination 2001 prescribes a maximum permitted benzene content for all grades of petrol of 1% volume by volume from 1 January 2006. Queensland, Western Australia and South Australia currently prescribe maximum permitted levels of benzene for petrol. These standards operate concurrently with the Fuel Standard (Petrol) Determination 2001.
(4) No. The Government is reducing the health and environmental risks of petrol use through standards to be implemented under the Fuel Quality Standards Act 2000.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 13 February 2002:

question.para: (1) Further to the answer to part (3) of question No. 2622 (Hansard, 25 September 2001, page 31235), has no further medical examination occurred in respect of Dr Colston's medical condition and hence fitness to stand trial.

(2) Further to the answer to part (4) of question No. 2622, is the conclusion of Dr Colston's life expectancy being months based on two medical reports by two eminent specialists compiled on 14 and 19 May 1999; if so, are these reports now over two years and four months old.
(3) Are the reports referred to in the answer to part (5) of question No. 2622 based on the same medical examinations performed by the two eminent specialists of 14 and 19 May 1999.

(4) Is it a fact that, in relation to Dr Colston's capacity to stand trial on twenty-eight charges of defrauding the Commonwealth through travel rorts, no medical examination of Dr Colston has taken place since 19 May 1999.

(5) Further to the answer to part (13) of question No. 2622 and the prediction that Dr Colston's life expectancy of months is now disproved, will he recommend to the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) that Dr Colston should be medically re-examined; if so, when will he recommend that re-examination.

(6) Further to the answer to part (14) of question No. 2622, was the review of Dr Colston's medical condition based on a paper review of the pre-existing medical reports of 14 and 19 May 1999, without obtaining fresh medical evidence.
(7) What evidence was relied upon by the DPP in making his review, in addition to the two medical reports of May 1999.
(8) Will he now reconsider his decision not to assess whether Dr Colston is now capable of standing trial on twenty-eight charges of defrauding the Commonwealth through travel rorts; if not, why not.

talker.name: Williams, Daryl, MP
Mr Williams
talker.role: Attorney-General

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Further medical evidence was obtained.
(2) Yes.
(3) Yes, and further medical evidence.
(4) See part (3).
(5) No. I refer to my answer to Question on Notice 2622 part (14).
(7) Further medical evidence and independent expert medical advice.
(8) No. I refer to my answer to Question on Notice No. 2622 part (14).

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 13 February 2002:

quote.para: (1) How many marriages were registered in Australia in 2001.
(2) How many divorce orders were made by the Family Court of Australia in 2001.
(3) What action is the Government taking to address the significant percentage of divorces occurring in Australia each year.
(4) What action is the Government taking to address the number of contraventions of Family Court orders.

talker.name: Williams, Daryl, MP
Mr Williams
talker.role: Attorney-General

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) I am advised that the Australian Bureau of Statistics will not be publishing the statistics for the relevant period until August 2002.
(2) I am advised that the Australian Bureau of Statistics will not be publishing the statistics for the relevant period until August 2002.
(3) The Government's primary objective in family policy is to assist people to develop and maintain healthy relationships.

My Department receives an administered appropriation for grants to Family Relationship Support Organisations, commonly known as Family Relationships Services Program (FRSP). The FRSP is jointly funded by my Department and the Department of Family and Community Services (FaCS). Under the FRSP, approximately 100 community-based organisations are contracted to provide a range of family support services. The total appropriation in 2001-2002 is $57.3 million.

Through my Department, community-based organisations are funded to provide a range of services aimed at assisting couples and families to resolve issues around separation and divorce. These services include family relationships counselling, family and child mediation and children's contact services. The appropriation in 2001-2002 is $26.1 million.

The responsibility of services provided by FaCS lies with the Minister for Family and Community Services. Through FaCS, community-based organisations are funded to provide a range of services aimed at assisting couples and families to maintain and enhance their existing relationships. These services include family relationships counselling, family relationships education, family skills training, men and family relationships services and adolescent mediation and family therapy. The appropriation in 2001-2002 is $27.6 million.

FaCS currently provides $3.6 million per annum to 46 Family Relationships Education (FRE) organisations. These services provide preventative programs which focus on providing information and skills to foster positive stable relationships. Trained educators provide guidance and support to assist couples to understand themselves and their partner better with the aim of promoting and sustaining healthy relationships.

FaCS is responsible for providing a preventative service known as Family Relationships Skills Training (FRST), which promotes positive parenting and non-violent problem solving by providing families with parenting and family functioning skills. FRST services target low income families, sole parents, locationally disadvantaged families and families of children with disabilities. Some also target indigenous families and those from diverse cultural and linguistic backgrounds.

FaCS also administers the Men and Family Relationships Initiative, a pilot service specifically targeting men and fathers. The aim is to assist men to manage a range of relationship difficulties with partners and ex-partners, children and step-children and to help organisations develop more sensitive and responsive approaches to working with male clients. A total of 54 projects in rural, regional and metropolitan Australia have been funded under this initiative. Many are generalist services that include counselling, relationship education and parenting skills programs but they are all designed to be attractive to men and to take men's particular help-seeking and problem solving strategies into account. The initiative has been allocated a total of $18 million over four years.

Further, FaCS administers Men's Line Australia, a national 24 hour telephone counselling information referral service. With a budget of more than $1.6 million over three years, Men's Line Australia seeks to provide relevant and accessible telephone counselling and referral services to men who are seeking to manage their relationships with partners, ex-partners and children, especially following divorce and separation. The primary target groups for the service are men facing separation and men experiencing difficulties managing their relationships with ex-partners and children. Other target groups include men seeking assistance with their partner relationships, but not facing or dealing with separation, and men experiencing difficulties in parenting children or step-children.

(4) The Government is aware of concerns about contraventions of orders of the Court. In response to these concerns amendments to the Family Law Act came into effect in 2000. The new arrangements utilise:

· preventative measures in the first instance (to encourage parents to seek assistance to improve communication between them and to assist their understanding of their joint parenting responsibilities);
· remedial measures if the first step is not effective (such as relationships programs to assist the parents to resolve conflicts about parenting); and

· punitive action as a final resort if the first two tiers are unsuccessful. The Family Law Act 1975, under Part IV, section 70 NG, provides sanctions for breach of parenting orders including directing the person to attend an appropriate post-separation program or counselling; imprisonment; community service orders and bonds.
Statistics pre and post amendments are not yet available. An evaluation of the current programs will take place in 2003.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 13 February 2002:

quote.para: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the coverage in the print media on the growing acquisition by private healthcare corporates of independent medical practices, particularly in a series in The Australian newspaper entitled “The Health Revolution”.

(2) Is there any Commonwealth agency which monitors and records the ownership and the change in ownership of medical general practices by private healthcare corporates such as Mayne Nickless, Foundation Healthcare, Endeavour Healthcare, Medical Care Services and Primary Healthcare.

(3) Is there any requirement for changes in the ownership of medical general practices to be advised to any Commonwealth agency, either prior to or after any acquisition of independent medical general practices by a private healthcare corporate.

(4) Is the Minister able to say whether the Foreign Investment Review Board is required to be advised by the private healthcare corporates with substantial foreign ownership prior to any acquisition by them of independent medical general practices.

(5) Is the Health Insurance Commission or any other Commonwealth agency in possession of any information regarding the comparative (a) cost of medical services provided and (b) rates of referral to downstream ancillary services such as pathology and radiology, by independent and corporate general practices.
(6) What are the comparative imposts of the independent and corporate (a) general practices and (b) downstream ancillary services practices and their relationship to the Health Budget.
(7) What measures will the Commonwealth put in place to protect patients of independent and corporate medical general practices in relation to their servicing practices and conduct.

(8) What measures will the Commonwealth put in place to protect a patient's right to choose either an independent or a corporate general practice in a patient's given locality, and have these rights been eroded or even eliminated by the complete acquisition of independent general practices by private healthcare corporates.

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
Mr Andrews
talker.role: Minister for Ageing

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) Yes.
(4) Acquisitions by medical corporations that meet the foreign interest criteria applied by the Foreign Investment Review Board (FIRB) may be notifiable and subject to review by the FIRB.

(5) The Health Insurance Commission (HIC) does not maintain any comparative national information about the cost of medical services provided, nor rates of referral to ancillary services, by independent and corporate general practices. However, the HIC did undertake a limited analysis of services rendered and ordered in the 1999-2000 financial year by a sample of incorporated and unincorporated general practices in Western Australia.
(6) This information is not available.

(7) The HIC routinely monitors doctors' service and referral patterns and undertakes enforcement action when required. These mechanisms apply to all doctors, no matter what type of practice they work in. In addition, in 2001 the Government worked closely with large corporate medical service providers, the AMA and the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners to develop a voluntary code of conduct to protect doctors' clinical autonomy and independence, and ensure that patients continue to receive appropriate, high quality services. The voluntary code was launched on 1 November 2001. It complements mechanisms already in place to detect and address over-servicing under the Health Insurance Act 1973.
(8) I am not aware of evidence that any patient's right to choose to attend either an independent or corporate general practitioner has been eroded by recent developments in corporate medicine.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 13 February 2002:

quote.para: (1) Does Australia have a reciprocal arrangement with the British Government for her Department to act as the contact agent in facilitating health requirements for ex-British servicemen and servicewomen who have accepted war related disabilities; if so, what are the details.

(2) Does the Australian Government invoice the British Government for each departmental client; if not, does the Australian Government negotiate a lump-sum each year for estimated costs of attending to ex-British servicemen.
(3) Can she describe how a person may peruse the accounting transaction referred to in part (2).

talker.name: Vale, Danna, MP
Mrs Vale
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) My Department has an arrangement with the British Government whereby DVA acts as an agent on behalf of the British War Pensions Agency. Under this arrangement, British ex-servicemen and women who have a disability accepted by the British War Pensions Agency as war-caused, are issued with a Repatriation Health Card - For Specific Conditions (White Card). The White Card allows British ex-service personnel access to the Repatriation Commission's health care arrangements for their accepted disabilities, which includes services such as:
· medical and specialist services;
· hospitalisation;
· allied health services, including dental and community nursing;
· rehabilitation aids and appliances;
· pharmaceuticals; and
· hearing services.

Since the treatment policies of the United Kingdom are not necessarily the same as those applying to veterans of the Australian forces, prior authorisation from the British War Pensions Agency is required for some services, such as hospital admission.

(2) The Australian Government invoices the British Government for the cost of services used by British ex-service personnel. These invoices are for the total amount of services provided to British ex-service personnel and are not issued on an individual basis. Invoices are issued monthly in arrears.

(3) The accounting transaction referred to in part 2, is set out in the Department of Veterans' Affairs Portfolio Additional Estimates 2001-02, Page 67, Table 3.6-Note of Budgeted Administered Financial Performance. The amount of $2,939,797,000.00 under Other Goods and Services includes an amount of $4,173,454.53, which is the total amount received from the British Government in financial year 2000-2001. This information can also be found in the Department of Veterans' Affairs Annual Report 2000-2001, Appendix 1, Page 325, listed under the Expenses from Ordinary Activities and adding the Health Care Payments & Other.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 13 February 2002:

quote.para: When will the Government grant a Gold Card to ex-servicemen and women who served in the Australian Armed Forces within Australia during World War II and who do not have qualifying service.

talker.name: Vale, Danna, MP
Mrs Vale
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: Qualifying service during World War II is one of the essential criteria for eligibility for the Gold Card. The Government believes priority for the Gold Card should be given to veterans who rendered qualifying service, that is those who incurred danger from hostile forces of the enemy and were exposed to the unique hardships and deprivations of combat.

However, because of concerns in some sections of the veteran community, including some World War II veterans, that some ex-servicemen and women may be missing out on entitlements because of perceived anomalies in the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 (VEA), the Government has appointed a Committee to undertake an independent review of these perceived anomalies.

The Review of Veterans' Entitlements will specifically examine the historical context and current interpretation of the provisions for qualifying service and consider perceived anomalies with eligibility for access to VEA benefits and qualifying service that might be raised by some World War II veterans, veterans of the British Commonwealth Occupation Forces in Japan, Australian participants in British atomic testing in Australia, Australian service personnel engaged in counter terrorist and special recovery training and other interested parties.
The Committee report is due to be submitted in mid-November 2002.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 13 February 2002:

question.para: (1) Were persons employed under the Social and Community Services New South Wales Award granted a salary increase with effect from 28 November 2001 by the NSW Industrial Relations Commission when it handed down its determination on 16 November 2001.
(2) Do the Commonwealth and the NSW Governments jointly fund the cost of the salaries of the majority of Community Services' employees covered by this award.
(3) Has the NSW Government committed to fully fund its share of the salary increase awarded by the Commission.
(4) Will the Commonwealth fully fund its share of the salary increase awarded by the Commission; if so, when; if not, why not.

talker.name: Anthony, Larry, MP
Mr Anthony
talker.role: Minister for Children and Youth Affairs

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Family and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) This is an issue for the New South Wales Government.

(2) The Commonwealth already funds organisations for changes in wage costs it therefore does not need to provide additional funding. In most cases, additional funding for increased wage costs is already provided to States and service providers through indexation of their grants. Funding covered by the Commonwealth-State Disability Agreement, for example, is indexed according to a composite index of wage costs and general price increases.
(3) This is an issue for the New South Wales Government.

(4) The Commonwealth already funds organisations for changes in wage costs it therefore does not need to provide additional funding. In most cases, additional funding for increased wage costs is already provided to States and service providers through indexation of their grants. Funding covered by the Commonwealth-State Disability Agreement, for example, is indexed according to a composite index of wage costs and general price increases.

This form of indexing is likely to have been to the advantage of recipients over the last five years, since indexation was increased, while the wage costs associated with the Social and Community Services Award have remained unchanged.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 13 February 2002:

quote.para: (1) Is he aware of the decision of the Full Court of the Family Court of Australia in T and S [2001] FamCA 1147, in particular the comments by Nicholson CJ that the case highlights a serious problem affecting the administration of justice in family law proceedings and that women who have suffered serious domestic violence may be unable to present their cases unaided in family law proceedings.
(2) Should a women who has suffered domestic violence be required to personally cross-examine the perpetrator of that violence in family law proceedings.
(3) What steps is the Commonwealth taking to ensure that women who have suffered domestic violence are properly represented in family law proceedings.

(4) Does he agree with the view of Chief Justice Nicholson presented in his judgement that the denial of legal aid in the circumstances seen in the present case appears to infringe the practical enjoyment of rights which are meant to be assured under both the Convention on the Elimination of Discrimination Against Women 1981 and the Declaration on the Rights of Disabled Persons 1975.

talker.name: Williams, Daryl, MP
Mr Williams
talker.role: Attorney-General

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Yes I am aware of the decision of the Full Court of the Family Court of Australia in T and S [2001] FamCA 1147 and the comments made by Chief Justice Nicholson.
(2) See the answer to part (3).

(3) Women who are victims of domestic violence and who seek protection in the Family Court of Australia can receive legal aid using Commonwealth funds. Under the current legal aid agreements, the Commonwealth Government is quite clear about where its priorities lie. Each agreement states that “protecting the safety of a child or spouse who is at risk is to be accorded the highest priority in making grants of aid in family law”. The Commonwealth Government's commitment in this regard could not be clearer.

Guidance for legal aid commissions in relation to the handling of domestic violence considerations is contained in Part 1 of the Commonwealth legal aid guidelines. The intention of the latter is to ensure consistency of treatment for domestic violence matters, whether State/Territory or Commonwealth, rather than to pick up matters which are properly classed as State or Territory matters. Additionally, a specific provision which addresses domestic violence considerations in the context of family law property matters has also been included. However, others in the justice system also have responsibilities if we are to protect women and children.

(4) The Commonwealth Government is committed to complying with its obligations under international law. To this end, the Government considers that its administration of the Commonwealth Legal Aid Program is consistent with its international law obligations, including its obligations under the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of Discrimination Against Women, a Convention that Australia signed in 1980 and ratified in 1983.

Although a Declaration made by the United Nations is not binding in its own right, the Commonwealth Government is committed to ensuring that its practices are consistent with the requirements set out in the Declaration on the Rights of Disabled Persons (1975). The legal aid policies of the Commonwealth are evidence of that commitment.

Therefore, the Commonwealth Government is of the view that the practical enjoyment of the rights covered by the Convention on the Elimination of Discrimination Against Women and referred to in the Declaration on the Rights of Disabled Persons are being observed.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 13 February 2002:

question.para: (1) Are there any precedents for a party or parties appearing before a Royal Commission to receive legal assistance from the Commonwealth; if so, in respect of which Royal Commissions was such assistance provided.

(2) Is it contemplated that the Commonwealth will provide legal assistance to any party or parties in respect of the HIH Royal Commission or the Royal Commission in respect of the building industry unions.

talker.name: Williams, Daryl, MP
Mr Williams
talker.role: Attorney-General

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Attorney-General's Department administers (under delegation from the Attorney-General) a scheme for legal and financial assistance called the Commissions and Inquiries Scheme (the Scheme).

Under the Scheme assistance may be available where the Attorney-General has ministerial responsibility for the subject matter of the Commission or Inquiry, or where, in a specific instance, the Government has determined that the Attorney-General will be responsible for the provision of financial assistance.

In the last 10 years, legal assistance has been provided to various parties appearing before the Commission of Inquiry into the Relations between the Civil Aviation Authority and Seaview Air (the `Seaview Inquiry') and the Paedophile Inquiry.
(2) A scheme of financial assistance for legal and related costs before the HIH Royal Commission and the Royal Commission into the Building and Construction Industry has been established.
This scheme is administered by the Legal Assistance Branch of the Attorney-General's Department.

Guidelines for the provision of financial assistance before the Royal Commissions have been developed. Consistent with the approach for other Commissions and Inquiries, assistance may be available where:
personal interests could be exposed to prejudice;
the person is a central figure in the proceedings; or
cross examination of the person is likely to assist the Commission.
As at 12 March 2002, assistance has been granted to 14 parties appearing before the Royal Commission into the Building and Construction Industry.
As at 12 March 2002, assistance has been granted to 15 parties appearing before the Royal Commission into HIH.

There exists a long-standing practice, endorsed by successive Attorneys-General, to treat applications for financial assistance in confidence. This practice extends to neither confirming nor denying that particular applications have been received in accordance with the requirements of the Privacy Act1988.

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 13 February 2002:

question.para: (1) Further to his answer to question No. 2259 (OfficialHansard, 23 May 2001, page 26950) concerning the appointment of a wine consultant for Kirribilli House, what is the brand name of each of the 58 dozen bottles purchased and what was the cost of each dozen.
(2) What is the full detail of the strategy/cellar plan used by the consultant on the advice of his Department.
(3) What arrangements apply with respect to the purchase of wine for The Lodge.
(4) Do any other Ministers have an entitlement to purchase wine at public expense; if so, which Ministers and what is their entitlement.
(5) Why were no wines purchased from Queensland.

talker.name: Howard, John, MP
Mr Howard
talker.role: Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: I am advised by my department as follows:

(1) Mr Peter Bourne was contracted to identify and recommend suitable Australian wines for use at the official residences. The specific recommendations made by Mr Bourne comprise information with a commercial value to him, which would be diminished if the information were publicly available. On that basis, I have nothing further to add to my response to question No. 2259.

(2) I have nothing further to add to my response to question No. 2259, which detailed the specification of requirements issued by my department for the development and implementation of the strategy/cellar plan.
(3) The contract with Mr Bourne is for the identification and recommendation of suitable Australian wines for use at both official residences.

(4) Ministers are responsible for any official hospitality they wish to provide, with costs being met by home departments. The procedures to be followed are matters for Ministers and their departments.
(5) No Queensland wines were recommended by Mr Bourne. My department has discussed this matter with Mr Bourne and Queensland wines will be fully considered in any future recommendations.

subdebateinfo.title: Civil Aviation Safety Authority: Legal Costs
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 106)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 13 February 2002:

question.para: (1) What sum did the Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) pay per day for the services of Mr A. Shand QC and Mr Ian Harvey to represent the organisation in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal matter involving Whyalla Airlines.
(2) What was the total cost incurred by CASA for the proceedings in relation to Whyalla Airlines and what is the detail of those costs, including internal CASA legal costs.
(3) What is the total sum paid by CASA for external legal services in each of the past five years.
(3) Is CASA paying a retainer to any barrister or solicitor; if so (a) who and (b) what sum is being paid.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: The Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) has provided the following advice:

(1) It has been the practice of consecutive Governments not to disclose information about the daily or hourly rates for individual counsel on the basis that arrangements between the Commonwealth and individual counsel are treated as confidential to protect the Commonwealth's financial interests.
The counsel were briefed in accordance with the Legal Services Directions issued by the Attorney-General under section 55ZF of the Judiciary Act 1903.
(2) The total estimated cost incurred by CASA in responding to the action taken by Whyalla Airlines in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal is $111,655.80. This comprises the following:
External legal costs of $66,450 (see 1 above).
Internal legal costs of $45,205.80 made up of:

· $39,120 (excluding tax and superannuation costs) for staff hours used in preparation for appearance at the AAT (this is based on an estimated 326 staff hours multiplied by an indicative hourly rate of $120 per hour); and $6,085.80 for acquisition of the hearing's transcripts.
(4) The Civil Aviation Safety Authority does not retain any Barrister or Solicitor.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 13 February 2002:

question.para: (1) Does the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act or the Airports Act guarantee that Bankstown Airport will have an Environmental Impact Statement for any airport expansion proposals, such as new passenger terminals, runway extensions and handling of larger aircraft like Boeing 737 aircraft; if so, which sections provide that guarantee and what is the impact of the proposed privatisation on those sections.
(2) Does the Airports Act require the completion of a Masterplan for Bankstown Airport, if so, has it been completed.
(3) If a Masterplan has not been completed as required, why not and when will it be completed.
(4) Has Bankstown Airport established a consultative committee as it was required to do by April 2000 in accordance with the Environment Strategy for the airport, if not, why not.

(5) Will that consultative body be empowered to discuss, analyse and provide solutions to noise and pollution impacts from aircraft arriving, departing, taxiing and overflying residents and who will be on that consultative body.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Any proposal for upgrading the facilities and operational status of Bankstown Airport will be subject to the assessment and consultation requirements of the Airports Act 1996 and the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 (EPBC Act). Proposals to build a new or enlarged terminal and to extend the runway would trigger the Major Development Plan (MDP) requirements of the Airports Act. These requirements include a formal 90 day public consultation period and consideration of the proposal by the Minister for Transport and Regional Services.

The EPBC Act requires that the advice of the Minister for the Environment must be sought and considered before an MDP, or a plan for aviation airspace management involving aircraft operations with a significant impact on the environment, is approved or implemented. In forming this advice, the Minister for the Environment may require an environmental assessment in one of the forms set out in the EPBC Act. I will be recommending that the private sector lessee should be required to do a full environmental impact statement into the upgrading of Bankstown Airport.

(2 & 3) The Airports Act 1996 requires that for each leased federal airport, there is to be an approved Master Plan. Given the impending sale of Bankstown Airport, I have extended the deadline for the submission of a draft Master Plan for Bankstown Airport to 30 September 2003 or no later than 12 months after the transfer of the lease to a new private operator.

(4) To date, Bankstown Airport Limited has demonstrated a solid commitment to implementing its Environment Strategy and, in my view, is progressing well in achieving its objectives. On the matter of the proposed Bankstown Airport Community Advisory Committee, I note the Airport's plan for an advisory forum comprising key airport tenants and operators, government agencies, industry associations and community representatives. I have asked my department to liaise with Bankstown Airport on implementing this arrangement at the earliest practicable opportunity.

(5) The terms of reference for the Committee are a matter for the management of Bankstown Airport. However, I would anticipate the Committee providing advice to the Airport and other aviation authorities on the abatement of aircraft noise and related environmental issues at Bankstown Airport, as well as consultation and information flows to the community about the Airport's operations.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 13 February 2002:

quote.para: (1) Where, and in which electoral divisions, are Migrant Resource Centres located.
(2) How many clients has each Centre assisted in each of the last 10 years.
(3) When was each centre established and how is the ongoing need for a Centre in a particular location regularly assessed.
(4) Is the Government considering the closure or opening of any Centre.
(5) How many refugees were assisted by each Centre over each of the last 10 years.

talker.name: Hardgrave, Gary, MP
Mr Hardgrave
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs

talk.start.para: —The answer to part (3) of Question No. 117 (Hansard, 13 March 2002, pages 1289-1291) provided incorrect establishment dates for the South Metro Migrant Resource Centre in Fremantle and the Northern Suburbs Migrant Resource Centre in Mirrabooka.

quote.para: The correct dates of establishment are 1981 for the South Metro Migrant Resource Centre in Fremantle, and 1994 for the Northern Suburbs Migrant Resource Centre in Mirrabooka.

subdebateinfo.title: Health and Ageing: Ethnic Aged Care Framework
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 125)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Ageing, upon notice, on 13 February 2002:

quote.para: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 2284 (Hansard, 25 June 2001, page 27009) and the Turkish Association of Victoria's loss of funding under the Government's Community Settlement Services Scheme at the same time as the Australian Greek Welfare Society and Co.As.It Victoria, were any requests made at the same time as the Australian Greek Welfare Society and Co.As.It Victoria for funding assistance under the Ethnic Aged Care Framework.
(2) Why were the grants transferred from the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs to the Department of Health and Aged Care not also transferred to the Turkish Association of Victoria.
(3) Was the Turkish Association offered encouragement to apply for funding from other sources; if not, why not.
(4) Does his Department provide any grants to the Turkish community in any other States and Territories; if so, what is the nature of those grants.

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
Mr Andrews
talker.role: Minister for Ageing

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (2) The only grants transferred from the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs to the Department of Health and Ageing were for the Australian Greek Welfare Society and Co.As.It Victoria.
(3) Not applicable, as grants for the Turkish community were not involved.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 14 February 2002:

quote.para: (1) Is the Minister aware of the Australian Communication Authority's (ACA) determination made under subsection 99(1) of the Telecommunications Act 1997 titled Telecommunications (Service Provider-Identity Checks for Pre-paid Public Mobile Telecommunications Services) Determination 2000.
(2) Does Part 3 of the determination make provision for the collection of information and verification of identity at point of sale of pre-paid mobile telecommunications services.

(3) Does paragraph 3.1 state that the Part sets out the rules that a carriage service provider must comply with if the carriage service provider chooses to collect information about, and, if necessary, verify the identity of, the purchaser of a pre-paid public mobile telecommunications service at the point of sale of the service.
(4) Is the operation of paragraph 3.1 at the discretion of the carriage service provider if it chooses to collect the information prescribed in Schedule 1 of the determination.

(5) Does the operation of paragraph 3.1 determine the operation of paragraphs (a) 3.2 (Requirements to be satisfied before service is activated), (b) 3.3 (Information to be collected about purchaser), (c) 3.4 (Verification of identity of purchaser - payment otherwise than by credit card or debit card) and (d) 3.5 (Verification of identity of purchaser - non-cash payment).
(6) Does Part 4 of the determination make provision for the post-sale collection of information and verification of identity of pre-paid mobile telecommunications services.

(7) Does paragraph 4.1 state that the Part sets out the rules that a carriage service provider must comply with if the carriage service provider chooses to collect information about, and, if necessary, verify the identity of, the end-user using the service that is automatically diverted to the carriage service provider after the completion of the sale of the service.
(8) Is the operation of paragraph 4.1 at the discretion of the carriage service provider if it chooses to collect the information prescribed in Schedule 1 of the determination.

(9) Does the operation of paragraph 4.1 determine the operation of paragraphs (a) 4.2 (Requirements to be satisfied before service is activated), (b) 4.3 (Information to be collected about end-user), (c) 4.5 (Obtaining identifying information about end-user) and (c) 4.7 (Procedures if required amount of identifying information cannot be verified).

(10) Do these discretionary powers in the hands of the carriage service provider or its agent, constitute industry self-regulation; if so, upon what policy rationale is this discretionary power in the hands of the carriage service providers based.
(11) What is the standing of the determination as an legal instrument enforceable by law.

(12) For the purposes of Part 5 of the determination, what value do such records have as a written record of pre-paid public mobile telecommunications service, in light of the discretionary provisions in Parts 3 and 4 of the determination which do not require collection of information.
(13) Is the quality and quantity of the written records prescribed in Part 5 determined by the quantity and quality of data that is discretionarily collected under Parts 3 and 4.
(14) Is the operation of Part 5 therefore dependent on the discretionary operation of Parts 3 and 4 of the determination.

(15) What procedures are in place to ensure that carriage service providers and agents of service providers as described in the Act, fulfil their statutory obligations under the determination, in particular the carriage provider's or agent's obligation in the supply of pre-paid public mobile telecommunications services in conformance with paragraph 2.2 of the determination.

(16) What criteria, if any, does the ACA use to determine whether a carriage service provider has properly exercised its discretionary power in fulfilling its obligations under paragraphs 3.1 and 4.1 of the determination.
(17) Has the ACA the power to compel a carriage service provider to collect information of the kind prescribed in Schedule 1.

(18) What evidence can be provided to show that the present scheme prescribed in the determination provides full and accurate data regarding the purported owners and true identity of pre-paid public mobile telecommunications services.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
Mr McGauran
talker.role: Minister for Science

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question, based on advice received from the Australian Communications Authority and the Department for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts:

quote.para: (1) Yes.
(2) Yes.
(3) Yes.

(4) No. If a carriage service provider chooses to collect information and verify the identity of a purchaser at the point of sale, the carriage service provider must collect information about the purchaser in accordance with 3.3. The only discretion that exists is whether the information is collected and verified using the process outlined in Part 3, or using the process outlined in Part 4.
(5) Yes.
(6) Yes.
(7) Yes.

(8) No. A carriage service provider has the discretion to implement a post sale information collection and verification process. If a carriage service provider chooses to implement a post sale process it must collect and verify information about the purchaser in accordance with Schedule 1.
(9) Yes.

(10) The carriage service provider's choice is whether to provide a point of sale verification process (Part 3) or a post sale verification process (Part 4). In the time since the determination was made in 2000, no reliable, accurate and complete database has been available to carriage service providers to conduct the post sale verification process. Accordingly each carrier has determined that the only implementation method available to carriage service providers is point of sale verification. The discretion that is provided for by the determination, enabling the carriage service provider to implement either a point-of-sale or a post-sale information collection and verification process, is a mechanism designed to foster the self-regulation of this particular and competitive segment of the telecommunications industry. That in turn is a reflection of the regulatory policy specified in section 4 of the Telecommunications Act 1997 that telecommunications be regulated in a manner that:
promotes the greatest practicable use of industry self-regulation; and
does not impose undue financial and administrative burdens on participants in the Australian telecommunications industry.
(11) The determination is subordinate legislation made under section 99 of the Telecommunications Act 1997 and is a disallowable instrument.

(12) Part 3 requires the carriage service provider to collect and if necessary verify information about the purchaser of a pre-paid service in accordance with the determination. Part 4 requires the carriage service provider to collect and if necessary verify the identity of the end user of a pre-paid service in accordance with the determination. The carriage service provider is not required to keep copies of the documents (e.g. photocopy of passport) but they must note what documents were provided to satisfy the requirements. Part 5 requires the carriage service provider to keep records of the information (as opposed to copies of the actual documents). Part 5 also requires carriage service providers to make arrangements with its agents to ensure the record keeping requirements under section 5.1 are kept.

The carriage service provider is required to record the information provided by the purchaser under either the point of sale process (Part 3) or the post sale process (Part 4). The records kept under Part 5 include: the name of the carriage service provider; the number issued by the carriage service provider for the services; for Part 3, the information collected under 3.3; and if applicable the kind of document seen by the carriage service provider under section 3.4 or 3.5; and in the case of a service purchased by credit or debit - details of the card, recorded in a way that can be linked to the number issued by the carriage service provider for the service.

Under Part 4 (not currently being used by any carriage service provider) the information to be collected includes the information collected under 4.3 and if the carriage service provider obtained and verified information about the end user under 4.5 and 4.6, the item numbers in column 1 of Schedule 3 that relate to the identifying information obtained and verified and the total number of points allocated to the identifying information; and if applicable the details of the kind of document seen by the carriage service provider under 4.6.

(13) The nature of the records kept by the carriage service provider under Part 5 are determined by whether the carriage service provider is operating a point of sale verification process (as all carriage service providers currently operate) or a post sale verification process. The carrier must record the requisite information in Part 5 depending on whether they implement a point of sale or post sale process. Records are required for each activated service.

(14) The discretionary power of carriage service providers is limited to whether they choose to operate a point of sale or post sale process. The record keeping obligations that relate to both parts are not discretionary.

(15) The Australian Communications Authority liaises regularly with law enforcement agencies and carriers through the forum of its Law Enforcement Advisory Committee regarding compliance with the determination.

(16) The ACA has recently convened a Working Group under the auspices of the Law Enforcement Advisory Committee to identify options for improving compliance with, and the operation of, the pre-paid mobile determination.

(17) A carriage service provider has the discretion to choose between a point of sale information verification process and a post sale verification process. All mobile carriers currently implement a point of sale process because of the reasons outlined in the answer to question 10. This issue will be considered as part of the Working Group process referred to in the answer to question 15.

(18) A carriage service provider must collect the information in Schedule 1 if it is activating a service under either section 3.3 or 4.3 of the determination. Failure to collect this information may be regarded as a breach of the determination which can result in the ACA issuing a formal warning, remedial direction, or commencing civil penalty proceedings (leading to a possible penalty of up to $10 million per contravention).

The ACA is currently investigating the operation of the determination in light of concerns expressed by law enforcement agencies to improve the pre-paid mobile telecommunications market from both the agency and carrier perspective.

However, it should be noted that the purchaser of a pre-paid mobile service is often not the end-user and advice from law enforcement agencies suggests that identity fraud is a significant enforcement concern in all areas of criminal investigation including those that relate to the purchasing of pre-paid mobiles. Law enforcement agencies have advised that in comparison with overseas jurisdictions, particularly in Europe and Scandinavia, the Australian pre-paid market is well regulated. The Law Enforcement Advisory Committee Working Group is investigating options to further improve identification and verification processes in the Australian pre-paid market.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 14 February 2002:

question.para: (1) How many notifications of dangerous goods being sent through the mail were received by the appropriate authorities for each month in 2001.
(2) For each notification, how many were revealed by investigation to be hoaxes.

talker.name: Williams, Daryl, MP
Mr Williams
talker.role: Attorney-General

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Generally, no central register is maintained for the number of dangerous goods being sent through the mail.

However, the Protective Security Coordination Centre within my Department activated the Watch Office in the early hours of 12 September 2001 in response to the terrorist attacks in New York and Washington. The Watch Office started to receive reports from State and Territory police services of suspicious packages received in Australia during the months immediately following the Anthrax mail incidents in the United States on 18 September 2001.

As at 31 October 2001, the Watch Office had received reports of 1895 incidents of suspicious packages. At the end of November the number had grown to 2738. Most police services stopped reporting such incidents in late November 2001. The Watch Office ceased maintaining consolidated lists of suspect packages on 4 December 2001. At that time, about 3000 suspect packages had been reported.
(2) Police reporting of, and the compilation of national statistics on suspect packages has proved to be inconsistent and has been complicated by definitional issues relating to the term `hoax'.

However, of the 1,895 incidents reported to the Watch Office as at 31 October 2001, 721 were classified as hoaxes. At the end of November 2001 this number had grown to 948 from a total of 2,738 incidents. None of the suspicious packages reported proved to be of genuine concern. As noted above, most police services stopped reporting such incidents in late November 2001 and when the Watch Office ceased maintaining consolidated lists of suspect packages on 4 December 2001, approximately one third of the 3000 suspect packages reported were designated as hoaxes.

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 18 February 2002:

talker.name: Howard, John, MP
Mr Howard
talker.role: Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: I am advised by the Official Secretary to the Governor-General that Government House makes available to all who wish to know that the Governor-General's formal title is “His Excellency the Right Reverend Dr Peter Hollingworth, AC OBE”

I am further advised that the basis of the Governor-General's use of the title “Doctor” is his receipt of a Lambeth Doctorate of Letters from the Archbishop of Canterbury on 22 May 2001. subdebateinfo.title: Australian Customs Service: Peter Tomson Case
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 146)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 18 February 2002:

quote.para: (1) Further to the Minister's answer to question No. 2586 (Hansard, 6 August 2001, page 29234) concerning the Peter Tomson case, (a) was the magistrate's decision that a prima facie case had been established based on averments sworn by the Australian Customs Service (ACS) to initiate the proceedings and (b) were these averments subsequently shown to be false.
(2) How many officers that provided evidence before the Midford inquiry were also involved in the Tomson case and what positions did they hold within the ACS.
(3) What are the terms of reference for the review of the Tomson case by Counsel.
(4) What guarantee can the Minister give to the independence of a review Commissioned by Customs itself.
(5) Can the Minister guarantee that all relevant ACS information will be placed before Counsel.
(6) Will Mr Tomson be interviewed by Counsel.
(7) When does the Minister expect Counsel's review to be completed.

talker.name: Williams, Daryl, MP
Mr Williams
talker.role: Attorney-General

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) (a) The transcript of the proceedings indicates that the Court found a prima facie case “... on the evidence contained in the documents and the evidence from .. (not transcribable) ...” The documents available to the Magistrate included averments sworn by officers of the Australian Customs Service. It appears clear that the Magistrate's decision that there was a prima facie case was not based on averments alone.
(b) No. Before finding a prima facie case existed, the Magistrate had ruled that some of the Customs averments dealt with questions of law not of fact and required them to be amended or disregarded.
(2) Two, a Director and a Chief Inspector.

(3) Customs advises that the instructions to Counsel were: “It would be appreciated if you would consider the material submitted by Messrs Barwick, Boitano Lawyers and the other material enclosed. Customs seeks your advice whether there is any substance in the allegations made and if further examination is warranted.”

(4) The request for review of material was made to Customs by Barwick, Boitano Lawyers on behalf of Mr Tomson. In view of allegations made in the material provided by Barwick, Boitano Lawyers, Customs considered it prudent that the material be independently examined and a report be forwarded to Customs. Counsel had no previous involvement with this matter and his independence and integrity are not in question.
(5) Customs advises that all the material placed before the Court in the Tomson matter along with the associated case files was made available to Counsel.
(6) Counsel did not indicate any need to interview Mr Tomson.

(7) Counsel provided his report to Customs on 24 September 2001. On the basis of the available material and the absence of further information from Mr Tomson's solicitors, Counsel concluded that the allegations were baseless and incapable of being particularised. On 7 December 2001 Customs advised Mr Tomson's legal representatives of Counsel's conclusions and provided a copy of a summary of those conclusions.
