talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 20 February 2002:

quote.para: (1) Since September 1994, how many (a) adults and (b) children are estimated to have lost their Australian citizenship due to the operation of section 17 of the Citizenship Act.
(2) What were the new countries of nationality or citizenship that triggered the loss of Australian citizenship.
(3) How many of the people referred to in part (1) have to date (a) applied for and (b) obtained a resumption of their Australian citizenship under section 23 of the Act.

talker.name: Hardgrave, Gary, MP
Mr Hardgrave
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Since September 1994, 2549 adults have been recorded as having lost their Australian citizenship due to the operation of section 17 of the Australian Citizenship Act 1948. In the same period, 363 children are recorded as having lost their Australian citizenship under section 23 of the Australian Citizenship Act 1948 as a result of their parents having lost under section 17.

(2) The loss of Australian citizenship is triggered by section 17 of the Australian Citizenship Act 1948. Section 17 provides that an adult Australian will lose their Australian citizenship if they do “any act or thing” which results in the acquisition of the citizenship of another country. By acquiring the citizenship of any country, a citizen will automatically lose their Australian citizenship. The Department does not collect statistics on which countries Australian citizens apply to for citizenship.

(3) Figures for financial years 1994/95 and 1995/96 are recorded only as the total number of people who have resumed. That is, there is no data break up for adults and children and no data on the number of applications lodged for resumption of Australian citizenship. In 1994/95 the total number of people who resumed their Australian citizenship was 292 and 424 in 1995/96.

Since financial year 1996/97, 2753 adults and 177 children have applied to resume their Australian citizenship. Of these, 2382 adults and 159 children have obtained a resumption of their Australian citizenship under sections 23A, 23AA and 23B of the Australian Citizenship Act 1948.

Departmental data on resumption does not record the means by which the applicant lost Australian citizenship. The adults and children referred to above as having resumed citizenship may have lost their citizenship either by renunciation (section 18 of the Australian Citizenship Act 1948) or through the operation of sections 17 and 23 of the Act.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 20 February 2002:

question.para: (1) With respect to the issue of road safety, is there a clear link between speed and serious accidents.
(2) Does the Government accept that speed advertising contradicts the primary road safety measure that speed kills.
(3) Has the Government considered the advertising code of the United Kingdom on automotive advertising and speed.

(4) Is he able to say whether the current Toyota Corolla television advertisement, the Mitsubishi VRX speeding bullet advertisement; the Holden Ute kicking up a storm advertisement; the Ford Ute wake-boarding ad and the Honda dreams would be unlikely to be permitted in the UK or other countries with similar advertising codes.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes, research has shown a clear link between speed and road safety. Speed affects the risk of involvement in a crash, crash severity and the probability of serious injury or death. Speed increases of just a few kilometers per hour have been shown to result in a significant increase in the risk of a serious crash.

(2) Road safety messages that seek to discourage excessive speed are an important part of road safety campaigns conducted by both government and non-government agencies throughout Australia. The Federal Government is concerned that vehicle advertising featuring an excessive emphasis on speed and power and aggressive and/or illegal driving has the potential to undermine these important safety messages. My Parliamentary Secretary, Senator Boswell, issued a media release on these concerns in December 2001.

(3) In the United Kingdom, three independent regulators enforce separate Codes of Practice for advertising: the Independent Television Commission, the Advertising Standards Authority and the Radio Authority. Each includes specific sections relating to motor vehicles, providing much more detailed guidance for advertisers than Australia's current Advertiser Code of Ethics.

The Australian Transport Safety Bureau, in my Department, recently made a written submission to the Australian Association of National Advertisers, drawing on input from safety bodies around Australia. The main proposal put forward by the ATSB in the submission is for the development of more comprehensive and specific guidance for manufacturers and advertisers, within the current framework of self-regulation.
The Australian Transport Safety Bureau considered the advertising codes of a number of other countries, including the UK and New Zealand, when developing its proposal for more comprehensive guidance.

Similar to the UK, New Zealand has a Code for Road Safety in Advertising which provides guidance to advertisers. The New Zealand Code lists specific unacceptable elements, including glorifying excessive speed and unsafe driving practices. In correspondence with the Australian Transport Safety Bureau, the New Zealand Land Transport Safety Authority noted that a number of advertisements originating in Australia were banned in New Zealand on the basis that they were considered to glorify excessive speed.

(4) Whether particular advertisements would be permitted in the UK or other countries is entirely a matter for those countries. I do not intend to speculate on how other countries might apply their own codes. There is a growing number of advertisements of potential concern in addition to those cited in the question, and the Government is seeking action by advertisers and the vehicle industry as a matter of priority.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 11 March 2002:

quote.para: Are Australian special forces on active service in Afghanistan (a) being tasked appropriately with those military operations they are specifically trained to performed, (b) operating with like special forces and (c) being resourced and supported to the same levels as those special force counterparts.

talker.name: Vale, Danna, MP
Mrs Vale
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (a) Yes, Australian Special Forces personnel are performing in a Special Forces role. These tasks typically include:
· Operating in small teams for extended periods in extremely rugged terrain;
· Accessing remote locations to observe al Qaeda and Taliban activities, which in this operation is beyond the scope of conventional Australian forces; and
· Conducting long-range patrols, beyond the range and scope of conventional Australian forces.
(b) Other coalition members do have Special Forces deployed within Afghanistan and Australian Special Forces are at times required to operate closely with them.

(c) Yes, Australian Special Forces personnel are being resourced and supported in line with their coalition counterparts. Prior to their deployment, the Australian Defence Force (ADF) procured a significant amount of special equipment to kit out the Australian Special Forces detachment for operations within Afghanistan. This included extreme cold weather equipment (special sleeping bags, tents, boots and other personal equipment), numerous all terrain vehicles, and special weapons and munitions. To maintain an appropriate level of support to the Special Forces detachment the ADF conducts a weekly sustainment flight to the Middle East. In addition, coalition members provide the Australian Special Forces detachment with aeromedical evacuation and health support as well as fuel, water and fresh food.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs: Salaries
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 177)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 11 March 2002:

quote.para: (1) Which organisations funded by the Minister's Department will face an increased salary bill as a result of the decision of the Industrial Commission of New South Wales in the social and community services employees (State) Award case matter no. IRC 5544 1998.
(2) Is it the case that the NSW Government has offered to increase grants to those organisations to assist in meeting those increased salaries.
(3) Will the Federal Government similarly increase grants to those organisations to assist them to cope with the increased salary commitment.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs cannot readily determine the number of funded organisations in NSW which face increased salary costs as a result of the recent Social and Community Services (SACS) Award increase.
- While funded organisations are required to adhere to relevant awards and conditions the Department is not involved in the negotiation of salaries or the employment of staff by funded organisations.
- The Department does not monitor the salary arrangements of funded organisations.
- Some funded organisations currently pay salaries that are higher than the new Awards rates, so the increase will not necessarily impact on all organisations funded by the Department.
NSW and ACT organisations and agencies currently receiving program funding by my Department appear in the table below.

(2) Yes. According to Hansard transcripts of 6 December 2001 the NSW Treasurer announced that the NSW Government “...is paying the full amount of its share to enable the non-government organisations to pay the increase to their staff.”

(3) Funds for this financial year are fully committed. Applications for funding in upcoming rounds for the Community Settlement Services Scheme (CSSS) and Living in Harmony (LIH) program are expected to reflect the new salary costs and should be costed appropriately.

Core funding to Migrant Resource Centres (MRCs)/Migrant Service Agencies (MSAs) does not contain a specific amount for salaries. MRC/MSA management committees manage their budget, expenditure and employment of staff independently, and make their own operational decisions.
On average, approximately 2 percent indexation per annum is applied to core funding to MRCs/MSAs.
Organisations in NSW and the ACT currently in receipt of funding from the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Children and Youth Affairs: Salaries
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 178)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Children and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 11 March 2002:

quote.para: (1) Which organisations funded by the Minister's Department will face an increased salary bill as a result of the decision of the Industrial Commission of New South Wales in the social and community services employees (State) Award case matter no. IRC 5544 1998.
(2) Is it the case that the NSW Government has offered to increase grants to those organisations to assist in meeting those increased salaries.
(3) Will the Federal Government similarly increase grants to those organisations to assist them to cope with the increased salary commitment.

talker.name: Anthony, Larry, MP
Mr Anthony
talker.role: Minister for Children and Youth Affairs

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Organisations that deliver the following FaCS programs that may be affected by the SACS award are:
- Disability Services - directly funded employment support and Commonwealth/State Disability Agreement (funding from FaCS to state government) and Carers
- Reconnect, Family Support Services, Youth Services and some Stronger Families and Communities Strategy Projects.
- Supported Accommodation Assistance Program (SAAP). Funding from FaCS to state government.
(2) This is an issue for the New South Wales Government.

(3) No. The Commonwealth already funds organisations for changes in wage costs, it therefore does not need to provide additional funding. In most cases, additional funding for increased wage costs is already provided to States and service providers through indexation of their grants. Funding covered by the Commonwealth-State Disability Agreement, for example, is indexed according to a composite index of wage costs and general price increases.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Health and Aged Care: Salaries
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 179)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Ageing, upon notice, on 11 March 2002:

quote.para: (1) Which organisations funded by the Minister's Department will face an increased salary bill as a result of the decision of the Industrial Commission of New South Wales in the social and community services employees (State) Award case matter no. IRC 5544 1998.
(2) Is it the case that the NSW Government has offered to increase grants to those organisations to assist in meeting those increased salaries.
(3) Will the Federal Government similarly increase grants to those organisations to assist them to cope with the increased salary commitment.

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
Mr Andrews
talker.role: Minister for Ageing

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) It is not the Commonwealth's role to become involved in matters associated with State awards.
(2) This is a question that should be addressed to the NSW Government.
(3) The Commonwealth Government provides cost indexation for all its community care programmes funded through this portfolio.

subdebateinfo.title: Stirling Electorate: Family Tax Benefit Debt Letter
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 180)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 11 March 2002:

quote.para: (1) How many families in the electoral division of Stirling received a Family Tax benefit debt letter?
(2) How many families residing in the postcode areas of (a) 6018, (b) 6019, (c) 6020, (d) 6021, (e) 6022, (f) 6029, (g) 6060, (h) 6061 and (i) 6062 received the Family Tax Benefit debt letter?

(3) What measures is the Government taking to ensure that people on commission based jobs and families where mothers return to the workforce are not penalised by the current Family Tax Benefit regime.

talker.name: Anthony, Larry, MP
Mr Anthony
talker.role: Minister for Children and Youth Affairs

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Family and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) As at 31 January 2002, 2890 families in the electoral division of Stirling received a Family Tax Benefit debt letter.

entry.para: Number of families who received a FTB debt letter as at 31 January 2002

quote.para: NB. It should be noted the information provided by postcode relates to the entire postcode and not just the electorate of Stirling.

(3) Eligibility for Family Tax Benefit is based on current year taxable income with full reconciliation of entitlement against actual income at the end of the tax year. This ensures that families receive the same entitlement whether they claim fortnightly payment, a lump sum or through the taxation system, and that families in comparable circumstances receive an equal amount of FTB in respect of any tax year.

Families can choose to receive their assistance either as fortnightly payments or through the taxation system. The Government recognises that some people, such as those working on commission and mothers returning to the workforce, may have difficulty in estimating their income and introduced strategies to assist these families.

People receiving fortnightly payments can revise their income estimate at any time, and payment is adjusted from the date the new estimate is received. The Family Assistance Office keeps in touch with families through telephone calls, letters and publicity to remind families to keep their income estimates up-to-date.

Families that have particular difficulty in providing a forward estimate of their income are able to claim assistance as a lump sum at the end of the tax year. In addition, if a family receiving fortnightly payments earns less income than they had estimated, the Family Assistance Office tops up their Family Tax Benefit at the end of the tax year. Well over 200,000 Australian families have already benefited from these top ups which were not available under the previous arrangements.

Of course people who start work part of the way through the tax year and add to the taxable income on which their Family Tax Benefit is based, are still financially better off than had they not worked. They will gain valuable work experience, and will benefit from access to the tax-free threshold on their own income and from tax cuts.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, Science and Training, upon notice, on 11 March 2002:

quote.para: (1) Can the Common Youth Allowance actual means test be applied along with the Socio-Economic Status (SES) measurement to measure more accurately the eligibility of non-government schools for Federal assistance; if not, why not.

(2) Is he satisfied that in all cases, the SES measurement will deliver equitable outcomes, and will not result in some schools receiving more or less funding vis-a-vis schools of similar socio-economic status; if so, why.
(3) Is he satisfied that the SES measurement will, in all cases, not unfairly advantage some students and some schools over others of equal or greater need; if so, why.

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
Dr Nelson
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Adding an actual means test to the socio-economic status (SES) model to measure the eligibility of non-government schools for Commonwealth assistance has many practical difficulties. The application of a means test (such as the Youth Allowance) would require assessment of about one million children in non-government schools adding considerable complexity to the funding scheme.
In contrast to the Youth Allowance and other family payments, the focus of Commonwealth recurrent funding is schools not individual students.

The SES model does not set out to measure the wealth of any individual or household but rather to obtain a relative measure of the socio-economic status of each school's community and to rank non-government schools in relation to each other.

The SES Index is comprised of three dimensions, education, occupation and income, which contribute equally to measure social advantage as well as disadvantage. This measurement provides a good proxy for parental income without the intrusiveness and administrative complexity inherent in means-testing parents more directly.

(2) Schools serving similar socio-economic communities will generate similar SES scores. However, the Government was concerned to provide security of funding for schools that would otherwise have their funding reduced by the move to the new funding system. The funding maintenance provisions ensure that no school will be financially disadvantaged.

(3) The SES model assesses the need of non-government schools for Commonwealth recurrent funding based on a measure of the socio-economic status of their school communities. Schools serving the neediest communities are funded at 70 per cent of the average cost of educating a child in a government school, whereas schools serving the wealthiest communities receive only 13.7 per cent of that cost.

subdebateinfo.title: Dormant Commissions of Administrators of the Commonwealth of Australia
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 183)

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 11 March 2002:

quote.para: (1) What are the names and positions of the (a) men and (b) women who hold dormant commissions as Administrators of the Commonwealth of Australia.
(2) What are the texts of their commissions.

talker.name: Howard, John, MP
Mr Howard
talker.role: Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Under the authority of section 4 of the Constitution, each State Governor holds a Commission from The Queen to administer the government of the Commonwealth of Australia. The Commissions are activated when required in the event of the absence, death, incapacity or removal of the Governor-General, in order of the Governors' seniority of appointment to State office.
(2) The Commission reads as set out in the attached document.
COMMISSION
passed under the Royal Sign Manual and the Great Seal of Australia, appointing
FULL NAME WITH POST NOMINALS,
to administer the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia in the event of the absence, etc., of the Governor-General

ELIZABETH THE SECOND, by the Grace of God Queen of Australia and Her other Realms and Territories, Head of the Commonwealth: To [title and name with post nominals in full], Governor of the State of [State], Greeting:

WE DO, by this Our Commission under Our Sign Manual and the Great Seal of Australia, appoint you, [title and name], in the event of the absence out of Australia, or the death, incapacity or removal, of Our Governor-General of the Commonwealth of Australia for the time being, to administer the Government of the Commonwealth, upon a request in that behalf being made to you in accordance with Our Letters Patent relating to the office of Governor-General of the Commonwealth of Australia.
AND WE DO hereby declare that this Our present Commission shall remain in force during Our pleasure.
Given at Our Court
at
on
by Her Majesty's Command,
Prime Minister

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 11 March 2002:

quote.para: (1) What is the rationale behind spraying passengers and cabin areas of planes entering Australia, given that insects and bacteria are likely to lodge in books and paper.
(2) Is the spray designed to reach those sections of the cabin.
(3) Are non-passenger areas sprayed.
(4) What is the spray and how powerful is it.
(5) What sum does the process cost.
(6) How is the spray's effectiveness measured.

talker.name: Truss, Warren, MP
Mr Truss
talker.role: Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's questions is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The `Report of the Informal Consultation on Aircraft Disinsection' commissioned by the World Health Organisation (WHO) 1995, states that `there is abundant evidence that vectors (of human diseases) can be transported internationally in both cargo and passenger carrying craft.'
The `Report into Aircraft Disinsection' (Naumann and McLachlan 1999), commissioned by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) concluded that:
· there is a significant risk that insects do occur in the cabins and holds of international aircraft bound for Australia from overseas;
· surveys have shown conclusively that disease outbreaks have been traced to this source; and
· disinsection kills these insects.

In response to this potential quarantine risk, Australia and some 43 other countries require that all arriving international aircraft are disinsected in order to help prevent the entry of a range of serious human health diseases such as Yellow Fever, Dengue Fever and Japanese Encephalitis.
Aircraft disinsection spraying has the additional effect of killing other insects that may pose a threat to Australia's agricultural industries and unique natural environment.
(2) Yes.
(3) Yes.
(4) There are two World Health Organisation (WHO) endorsed chemicals used in AQIS approved disinsection arrangements. These chemicals are:
· D-phenothrin—a `knock down' insecticide effective against a broad range of insect pests; and
· Permethrin—a contact insecticide effective against a broad range of pests, having good residual activity against crawling or flying insects.
D-phenothrin and permethrin are synthetic pyrethroids.
(5) The cost of aircraft disinsection is managed and paid for directly by international airlines flying into Australia.

(6) The effectiveness of residual disinsection treatments is audited using live-fly bioassays. This involves the measurement of fly knock down rates of specially bred flies that are placed in pre-determined locations within an aircraft.
Additionally AQIS managed vector monitoring programs monitor for the presence of exotic mosquitoes in and around international ports, consistent with the International Health Regulations.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 11 March 2002:

answer.para: (1) The design of the incoming passenger card is regularly reviewed in consultation with other organisations which have a particular interest in it, including the Australian Customs Service, the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service, and the Australian Bureau of Statistics. The most recent review of the card was undertaken in March 2002. Readability factors are taken into consideration as part of this regular review process.
(2) Feedback from users of the card is taken into account in the on-going refinement of the passenger cards design.
(3) As an aid to those whose first language is not English, the incoming passenger card is available in the following translations:
Arabic;
Chinese Simplified;
Chinese Traditional;
Greek;
Indonesian;
Italian;
Japanese;
Korean;
Malay;
Spanish;
Thai; and
Vietnamese.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 11 March 2002:

quote.para: (1) Is the Minister able to say whether the Australian Radio Network (ARN) owns the radio stations The Edge (formerly One FM), Mix FM and WS FM.
(2) Under broadcasting legislation, is a radio operator only permitted two radio stations per market.

(3) Is it a fact that (a) One FM and WS FM were both western Sydney based radio stations which delivered quality radio broadcasting services to a western Sydney population of almost 1.5 million, including local news and local content and (b) One FM and WS FM provided a cost effective communications medium for local western Sydney businesses to advertise and to reach new local customers.

(4) Is it a fact that the Australian Broadcasting Authority (ABA) approved ARN's purchase of One FM in 1998 on the basis that the three stations were in separate geographical regions, namely The Edge in Penrith, WS FM in Seven Hills and Mix FM in Neutral Bay.
(5) Is it a fact that when 2WS-FM was launched on 23 November 1978 it had a specific charter to provide a service for Sydney's growing western region.
(6) Are ARN's two western Sydney stations, The Edge and WS FM, now located in North Ryde with ARN's third station, Mix FM, also based in North Ryde.

(7) What implications does the decision of the three radio stations to relocate to North Ryde have on (a) the ABA's 1998 decision to allow the ARN to purchase a third station on basis that they were in different geographical regions and (b) the western Sydney based content and the western Sydney based news which was formerly broadcast on One FM located in Penrith and 2WS FM located in Seven Hills.

(8) What commitment can the Federal Government give to ensure that the 1.5 million people of western Sydney have a western Sydney based radio station that provides local content and local news stories while also providing an advertising medium for local businesses.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
Mr McGauran
talker.role: Minister for Science

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) Yes.

(2) Yes. Under section 54 of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992 (the BSA), a person must not be in a position to exercise control of more than 2 commercial radio broadcasting licences in the same licence area.

(3) (a) One FM is licensed to broadcast into the Katoomba licence area (population 267 970) covering the Blue Mountains area west of Sydney and includes Penrith, Richmond and Windsor on the western outskirts of Sydney.

WS FM is licensed to broadcast into the Western Suburbs Sydney licence area (population 1 391 462) extending roughly from Parramatta and Liverpool in the east to the foot of the Blue Mountains in the West.
The ABA has advised that both services continue to provide local news and content.
(b) Both services are licensed only to serve their respective licence areas. The ABA has advised that both services continue to provide advertising targeted to and focussed on western Sydney.

(4) It is not a requirement for the ABA to approve the acquisition of radio licences. Under section 63 of the BSA a person who comes into a position to exercise control of a licence must notify the ABA of that fact within 7 days. ARN is understood to have complied with this obligation.

If the ABA finds that a person is in a position to exercise control of more than 2 commercial radio licences in the one licence area it is empowered under the BSA to take appropriate enforcement action. ARN's acquisition on One FM is understood to not have breached any provision of the BSA.

(5) 2WS-FM is licensed to serve the Western Suburbs Sydney licence area. Each commercial radio broadcasting licence is subject to the following condition at subclause 8(2)(c) of Schedule 2 of the BSA:

“the licensee will not provide commercial radio broadcasting services under the licence outside the licence area of the licence unless the provision of those services outside the licence area occurs accidentally or as a necessary result of the provision of commercial radio broadcasting services within the licence area.”
(6) The three stations are understood to operate out of facilities located in North Ryde.
(7) (a) There is no requirement for the ABA to approve the purchase of radio licences. ARN's acquisition of One FM is understood to not have breached any provision of the BSA.

(b) The WS FM, One FM and Mix FM services are licensed only to serve their respective licence areas. The geographical location of ARN's broadcast facilities does not alter this requirement. WS FM and One FM are understood to continue to distinguish themselves as radio services for the people of western Sydney and the Blue Mountains, respectively.

(8) WS FM is licensed to serve the Western Suburbs Sydney licence area and One FM the Katoomba licence area. The ABA is empowered under the BSA to impose additional conditions on broadcasting licences as necessary.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 11 March 2002:

quote.para: (1) How many tenders were received to scuttle the decommissioned HMAS Brisbane at the Sunshine Coast.
(2) What was the decision making process for the tender and what criteria were applied to select the successful tender.
(3) Was a full and independent study done of the environmental and economic impact of each tender.
(4) Were the safety implications of each tender considered.
(5) Did the decision making process involve a survey of the effect of each tender on Queensland tourism.

talker.name: Vale, Danna, MP
Mrs Vale
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) No tenders were received. Following representation from the Queensland State Government, the Government agreed that the ex HMAS Brisbane be gifted to the people of Queensland as a dive site off Point Cartwright on the Sunshine Coast.

(2) The Minister for Defence is responsible for approving disposal decisions for major equipment such as the ex HMAS Brisbane. Selection of a suitable bid is based on cultural factors, such as historical or heritage links, and the ability of the bidder to successfully meet the financial and management outcomes of the bid. In this instance, the ex HMAS Brisbane has heritage links with the State of Queensland. Also, the Queensland State Government has advised their intention to develop a business plan and to manage implementation of their proposal for the ex HMAS Brisbane to be sunk as a dive site off the Sunshine Coast.

(3) No. The decision making process did not consider environmental and economic impacts. In this case, the environmental and economic impact of the project is the responsibility of the Queensland State Government. The Premier of Queensland, the Hon Peter Beattie, has advised that a detailed business plan will be developed to support the implementation of the proposal. The Queensland State Government commissioned Sinclair Knight Mertz to conduct preliminary site investigations that included environmental assessment of potential sites. The National Centre for Tourism was engaged to examine potential economic benefits of the project.
(4) No. The decision making process did not consider safety implications. These considerations are the responsibility of the Queensland State Government.

(5) No. The decision making process did not consider the effects on Queensland tourism. However, the Queensland State Government commissioned the National Centre for Tourism to examine the potential economic benefits of the project.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 11 March 2002:

quote.para: (1) In the last 5 years what was the total number of (a) humanitarian/refugee stream migrants and (b) family stream migrants born in English Proficiency (EP) group 3 and 4 countries who settled in (i) each local government area in metropolitan Sydney, (ii) the Hunter and Illawarra regions, (iii) rural NSW, (iv) each local government area in metropolitan Melbourne, (v) rural Victoria, (vi) Queensland, (vii) WA, (viii) SA, (ix) Tasmania, (x) the ACT and (xi) the NT.

(2) What research, if any, has the Government commissioned since 1996 on the factors that influence the initial settlement location of humanitarian/refugee stream migrants and their subsequent movement patterns.

(3) Does the Government offer any incentives to smaller States or individual councils that wish to accept larger numbers of humanitarian/refugee stream migrants; if so, what are the details; if not, is the Government willing to consider any such proposals positively.

talker.name: Hardgrave, Gary, MP
Mr Hardgrave
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Tables (i) to (xi) below contain the data requested on humanitarian and family stream arrivals. Data is sourced from the Department's Settlement Data Base and pertain to Family Stream and Humanitarian Stream arrivals over the five years from 1 January 1997 to 31 December 2001.

Data on state or territory of settlement comes from a variety of sources, and is available for about 97%-98% of arrivals. Tables (vi)-(xi) which pertain to migrant settlement totals for whole states or territories are likely to be accurate within a few percent of actual numbers.

Data on location of settlement at a finer geographic level is based on migrants' intended addresses, provided to the Department voluntarily. This information is not available for about 25% of arrivals. As a consequence, Tables (i)-(v) (marked with an asterisk), which pertain to settlement in Local Government Areas and Statistical Divisions, are likely to understate actual numbers more significantly.

(2) No research has been commissioned since 1996 on factors influencing the initial settlement location of humanitarian entrants. The initial location of humanitarian entrants is determined by factors that assist entrants to settle into the community. These include an adequate local presence of: contractors delivering services through the Integrated Humanitarian Settlement Strategy; Adult Migrant English Program services; employment opportunities; communities of similar background that can help support new arrivals; and appropriate medical services and schools.

(3) Incentives are not offered by the Government to smaller States or individual councils to accept larger numbers of Humanitarian entrants. There are no plans to provide such incentives. However, requests for larger intakes from states and territories, such as by Tasmania, are accommodated to the extent possible.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 11 March 2002:

quote.para: (1) In the latest year for which data is available, how many eligible clients received Adult Migrant English Program (AMEP) (a) classroom/community based formal tuition and (b) Home Tutor Scheme assistance in (i) southern Sydney, (ii) western Sydney, (iii) south-western Sydney, (iv) Illawarra, (v) inner city and eastern Sydney, (vi) Burwood, (vii) Hornsby, (viii) Newcastle and (ix) rural NSW.
(2) In the same year how many eligible clients received tuition in NSW under the AMEP Distance Learning Program.
(3) Are eligible clients in Sydney entitled to attend AMEP classes outside their region of residence and; if so, what proportion of clients actually do so.

(4) Have concerns been expressed that potential clients in some regions of NSW are not being referred to the AMEP Distance Learning Program; if so, what action has his Department taken in response to these concerns.
(5) What is the estimated total annual value of Commonwealth funding for AMEP service provision in NSW for 2001-2002.

talker.name: Hardgrave, Gary, MP
Mr Hardgrave
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The Department collects AMEP data on the basis of the five contract regions in NSW which are as follows: (i) South Sydney and Illawarra, (ii) Western Sydney, (iii) South Western Sydney, (iv) Inner City and Eastern, (v) Burwood, Hornsby, Newcastle and Rural NSW. The latest year for which data is available is for the calendar year 2001. The number of clients who have received classroom/community based tuition and assistance from a Home Tutor in the five regions in 2001 is as follows:

entry.para: (v) Burwood, Hornsby, Newcastle and Rural NSW

quote.para: (2) In 2001 a total of 977 clients received tuition in NSW under the AMEP Distance Learning Program.

(3) AMEP clients may attend classes outside their region of residence. Currently approximately 15% of all clients in NSW are attending classes in a contract region outside of the region in which they live.

(4) The possibility that potential clients in some regions of NSW are not being referred to the AMEP Distance Learning Program has been suggested to the Department however no substantive evidence has been provided to support the claim. The two Providers for AMEP services in NSW have a protocol of procedures in place for the referral of clients to the Distance Learning program. Promotional material and information on the Distance Learning program is made available by both Providers. Potential clients can also call a toll free course information telephone number. Client participation in the various learning options available under the AMEP is monitored through the Contract Management process. If it were found that clients were not being referred to the Distance Learning program the matter would be addressed by the Department with the relevant Service Provider.
(5) The estimated total value for AMEP service provision in NSW for 2001-2002 is expected to be approximately $44.5 million.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 12 March 2002:

quote.para: (1) Between 1964 and 2000 is he able to say whether the Government of Malta required young people of Maltese descent to renounce their Australian citizenship before their 19th birthday in order to retain their Maltese citizenship; if so, how many Australians took formal action to renounce their Australian citizenship during this period.
(2) What loss of Maltese entitlements did these young people face if they did not renounce their Australian citizenship in accordance with this requirement.
(3) What specific requirements must those referred to in part (1) meet in order to have Australian citizenship restored to them.

(4) How many of those referred to in part (1) have formally applied to resume Australian citizenship and of these, how many applications (a) have been approved, (b) have been rejected and (c) are still under consideration.

talker.name: Hardgrave, Gary, MP
Mr Hardgrave
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) It is my understanding that prior to 10 February 2000 a person who held Maltese citizenship by descent and the citizenship of a foreign country were required by Maltese law to make a choice as to which citizenship they wished to retain. This choice had to be made between their eighteenth and nineteenth birthday. If the person did not renounce their foreign citizenship they automatically lost their Maltese citizenship.

The Department's database, which collects statistics on renunciation of Australian citizenship, does not contain complete information on the nationalities of each applicant who has renounced their Australian citizenship. The number of Maltese who renounced their Australian citizenship is therefore not available.
(2) I understand that Maltese citizens were entitled to the following services, which Australian citizens living in Malta prior to 2000 were not entitled:
· Free tertiary education and a stipend from the government of Malta.
· Access to employment in occupations such as the public service, banks, armed forces and legal professions. Foreign passport holders were required pay a fee each year to obtain a licence to work.
· Ability to purchase any property. Foreign passport holders are required to obtain a permit to purchase property and may only purchase property above a minimum value.
· Ability to own more than one property at any time.
· Eligible to apply for less expensive house and land packages.
· Eligible to apply for subsidised rental or purchase of property.
· Entitled to have more than one bank account and not required to identify the source of each deposit of funds into that account.
· Easier access to credit card facilities.
· Easier access to bank loans, a longer period over which to pay off the loan and access to a lower interest rate on the loan, and

· Access to social security benefits for themselves and their foreign passport holder spouse. (Foreign passport holders who are not married to Maltese citizens are not eligible for some social security benefits).
My Department does not possess details of any variations to these entitlements, which only Maltese citizens were able to claim, which may have occurred over the period 1964 and 2000.

(3) Adults who have renounced Australian citizenship in order to retain another citizenship, such as the case with those people who held Maltese citizenship, can apply to acquire Australian citizenship by grant. They must wait at least 12 months from the time they lost their Australian citizenship to apply to acquire it and must meet the criteria for grant of Australian citizenship. That is:
· be of good character;
· possess a basic knowledge of English;
· have an adequate knowledge of the responsibilities and privileges of Australian citizenship; and if granted citizenship,
· be likely to reside or continue to reside in Australia or to maintain a close and continuing association with Australia.

While they must have been present in Australia as a permanent resident for 12 months in the two years immediately before lodging their application for the grant of citizenship they are not required to meet the two years in Australia in the past 5 years provision.

Under the Australian Citizenship Act 1948 there is currently no provision for a person who renounced their Australian citizenship in order to retain another citizenship to apply to resume their Australian citizenship.

However, following the passage of the Australian Citizenship Legislation Amendment Bill 2002 through both houses of parliament, from the date of proclamation, those people who renounced their Australian citizenship in order to retain another citizenship will have the capacity to apply to resume their Australian citizenship up to the age of 25 years. The criteria for resumption in this circumstance is the same as the current resumption provisions with the exception that applicants are not required to state that they did not know that they would lose their Australian citizenship.
The current provisions for resumption of Australian citizenship for an adult who has lost Australian citizenship by taking some action to acquire another citizenship are as follows.
The first requirement is that the person:
· did not know that they would lose Australian citizenship; or

· would have suffered significant hardship or detriment had they not acquired the other citizenship or, if the significant hardship or detriment were of an economic nature, the circumstances that caused them to take out foreign citizenship must be compelling.
The other requirements are that the person:
· has been lawfully resident in Australia for a total of at least two years in their life; and
· states that they intend to continue to reside in Australia or intend to commence residing in Australia within three years; and
· have maintained a close and continuing association with Australia.
A child under 18 years of age may be able to resume Australian citizenship by being included in a parent's application for resumption.

(4) Schedule 2 of the Australian Citizenship Legislation Amendment Bill 2002 will be proclaimed on 1 July 2002. There have, therefore, been no applications from Maltese citizens, seeking to resume their Australian citizenship under these new provisions.

No statistics are kept on those Maltese citizens who have reacquired their Australian citizenship by grant between 1964 and 2001 after previously renouncing their Australian citizenship. It is, however, estimated that approximately 37,000 Maltese citizens were granted Australian citizenship between January 1965 and June 2001.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 12 March 2002:

quote.para: (1) Did the US International Trade Commission (ITC) recommend to President Clinton on 27 March 1999 that higher tariffs and import quotas be applied to lamb imports.
(2) What were the import quotas and tariffs on lamb announced by President Clinton on 7 July 1999.

(3) Between 27 March and 7 July 1999, how many times did the Prime Minister and he discuss the ITCs recommendations and the potential for quota imposition and tariff increases on lamb with their US counterparts.
(4) How many times did the Prime Minister and he discuss the new lamb import restrictions with their US counterparts after 7 July 1999.

(5) How many (a) written and (b) oral representations did Australian Embassy staff in Washington make to Clinton Administration officials on the lamb import restrictions between 27 March and 7 July 1999.
(6) How many (a) written and (b) oral representations did departmental staff in Canberra make to the US Embassy on the lamb import restrictions between 27 March and 7 July 1999.
(7) Did the ITC recommend to President Bush on 19 December 2001 that higher tariffs and import quotas be applied to steel imports.

(8) How many times did the Prime Minister and he discuss the ITCs recommendations and the potential for quota imposition and tariff increases on steel with their US counterparts between 19 December 2001 and 5 March 2002, when President Bush announced he would impose import quotas and higher tariffs on steel.
(9) How many times have the Prime Minister and he discussed the new steel import restrictions with their US counterparts since 5 March 2002.

(10) How many (a) written and (b) oral representations did Australian Embassy staff in Washington make to Bush Administration officials on the steel import restrictions between the handing down of the ITCs decision and the announcement of the import quotas and higher tariffs by President Bush.

(11) How many (a) written and (b) oral representations did departmental staff in Canberra make to the US Embassy on the steel import restrictions between the handing down of the ITC decision and the announcement of the quotas and higher tariffs by President Bush.

talker.name: Vaile, Mark, MP
Mr Vaile
talker.role: Minister for Trade

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: The Government mounted vigorous lobbying campaigns when the United States considered and imposed unreasonable safeguard measures restricting imports of both Australian lamb and Australian steel. In the case of lamb, Australia initiated and won a World Trade Organization action and negotiated a speedy end to the import restrictions. In the case of steel, the Government made urgent representations with the result that between 70 and 85 per cent of Australia's current steel exports will not be affected (the range is attributable to volume/value differences). The Government reserves the right to take further action on steel.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 12 March 2002:

question.para: On the most recent data, what is the incidence of reported crime by type in (a) Victoria and (b) the postcode areas of (i) 3036, (ii) 3037, (iii) 3038, (iv) 3043, (v) 3046 (vi) 3047, (vii) 3048, (viii) 3049, (ix) 3059, (x) 3060, (xi) 3061, (xii) 3064, (xiii) 3427 and (xiv) 3428.

talker.name: Williams, Daryl, MP
Mr Williams
talker.role: Attorney-General

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (a) I am advised that according to the most recent data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics, the number of victims by offence category, for offences recorded by Police, in Victoria for 2000 was as follows:
Homicide and related offences - 169 victims. These can be broken down as follows:
(i) Murder - 55.
(ii) Attempted Murder - 51.
(iii) Manslaughter - 12.
(iv) Driving causing death - 51.
Assault - 16,541 victims.
Sexual assault - 2,474 victims.
Kidnapping - 106 victims.
Robbery - 3,326 victims. This can be broken down as follows:
(i) Armed robbery - 1,785.
(ii) Unarmed robbery - 1,541.
Blackmail/extortion - 69 victims.
Unlawful Entry with Intent - 78,774 victims. These can be broken down as follows:
(i) Property Theft - 62,654.
(ii) Other - 16,120.
Motor vehicle theft - 36,591 victims.
Other theft - 141,219 victims.
Source: Australian Bureau of Statistics, Recorded Crime: Australia 2000.

(b) I am advised that the Australian Bureau of Statistics does not produce data on the incidence of recorded crime by local area in Victoria, including by postcode. However, I am advised that such information may be available from the Victorian Police.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, Science and Training, upon notice, on 12 March 2002:

quote.para: What sums were provided to (a) government and (b) non-government schools in (i) 2000-2001 and (ii) 2001-2002 in the postcode areas of (A) 3036, (B) 3037, (C) 3038, (D) 3043, (E) 3046 (F) 3047, (G) 3048, (H) 3049, (I) 3059, (J) 3060, (K) 3061, (L) 3064, (M) 3427 and (N) 3428 and what was the (I) expenditure on, (II) location of and (III) purpose of, each grant.

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
Dr Nelson
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: Funding provided by the Department of Education, Science and Training is not allocated or reported on the basis of postcodes or electorates.

However, information on Capital Grant funding for government and non-government schools and General Recurrent Grants funding and Establishment Grant funding to non-government schools has been compiled on the basis of data available at the postcode level.
CAPITAL FUNDING (Non-Government Schools)

Commonwealth capital grants for schools are provided to improve educational outcomes by assisting in the provision of school facilities, particularly in ways that contribute most to raising the overall level of educational achievement of Australian school students.
Between 2000-02 the following non-government schools in the above listed postcodes received Capital funding:

quote.para: GENERAL RECURRENT GRANTS FUNDING (Non-Government Schools)
* Estimated Entitlement

The specific objective for the General Recurrent Grants programme is to help schools with the recurrent costs of school education so that they can offer students educational programmes directed towards the achievement of the Commonwealth's priorities for schooling.
ESTABLISHMENT GRANTS FUNDING (Non-Government Schools)
* Paid to date

The specific objective for the Establishment Grants programme is to assist new non-government schools with costs incurred in their formative years and to enable them to be more competitive with existing schools.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 12 March 2002:

quote.para: (1) How many Australian manufactured pianos are located in Australia's overseas missions and posts.
(2) Is he able to say whether Overs and Stuart pianos are (a) the only manufacturers of pianos in Australia and (b) highly regarded quality musical instruments.
(3) Will he take steps to ensure that Overs and Stuart pianos are placed in overseas missions where and when opportunities arise.

talker.name: Downer, Alexander, MP
Mr Downer
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's questions is as follows:

quote.para: (1) None.
(2) (a) and (b) I am aware that Overs and Stuart pianos are highly regarded musical instruments.

(3) I understand, from information the Department obtained directly from Stuart & Sons in May 2000, that the grand pianos produced by Stuart & Sons are custom made and cost in the vicinity of A$160,000 to A$185,000 with a construction time of approximately 12 months. Posts are not in the business of producing large scale or frequent professional music recitals. The Government seeks to promote the purchase of Australian items for its offices and residences overseas wherever possible in keeping with the purchasing guidelines issued by the Competitive Tendering and Contracting Authority (CTCA) which emphasise the need to obtain value for money. As Overs and Stuart pianos are specialist and costly instruments, the performance standards of which significantly exceed the Department's modest requirements implementation, of a purchasing policy dictating purchase of Australian made pianos would be at odds with the CTCA guidelines.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 14 March 2002:

quote.para: Did the Senate Estimates response show that estimated monies in the Natural Heritage Trust on 31 December 2000 totalled $691m, and that disbursements from the Trust since then for the period 1 January to 30 June 2001 were $167m; if so, what remaining money has been disbursed since then.

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr Kemp
talker.role: Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: Yes, these figures were given in response to a Budget Estimates question asked by Senator Bolkus on 5 June 2001 (Question no. 176 Senate Environment, Communications, Information Technology & the Arts Legislation Committee).
In the period 1 July 2001 to 28 February 2002, $139m has been disbursed.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 14 March 2002:

quote.para: Did the Greenhouse Allies Grant Arrangements for 1999-2000 include (a) $30,000 to the Australian Industry Group, (b) $30,000 to the South Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation and (c) $6205 for the Northern Territory Chamber of Commerce and Industry; if so, how was this money spent and what greenhouse gas abatement was achieved as a result.

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr Kemp
talker.role: Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: Yes, the Greenhouse Allies Grant Arrangements for 1999-2000, included payments of $30,000 to the Australian Industry Group, $30,000 to the South Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation and $6205 for the Northern Territory Chamber of Commerce and Industry.

Under the terms of their individual grants, these organisations promoted the benefits of greenhouse gas abatement and acted as `Partners' in mentoring and assisting groups of small enterprises, known as `Allies', to develop and implement cost effective energy efficiency and waste minimisation practices.
The Australian Industry Group directly assisted 11 organisations to implement cost effective environmental best practice measures that achieved greenhouse gas abatement of 13,264 tonnes.

The South Australian Wine & Brandy Corporation program focused on raising awareness, developing an `Australian Wine Environment Strategy' and linking greenhouse gas emission to other significant environmental issues impacting upon the wine industry. It is not possible to quantify savings at this time as abatement for the participating enterprises will not be realised and reported until after the 2002 Vintage.

The Northern Territory Chamber of Commerce and Industry Program provided assistance through energy audits, development of action plans and education to 30 small to medium sized enterprises within the service and manufacturing sectors. The program delivered abatement of 258 tonnes that equates to a percentage greenhouse gas reduction of between 7-14 % for the participating enterprises.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 14 March 2002:

quote.para: (1) What sum was left in the Greenhouse Challenge program as of 1 June 2001.
(2) What sum from the program remains unspent.

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr Kemp
talker.role: Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The Greenhouse Challenge appropriation in the 2001-2002 financial year was $7.475m and the estimate for 2002-2003 is $5.779m.
(2) $2.446m of the 2001-2002 appropriation remains unspent as of 31 March 2002. The estimate for 2002-2003 remains unchanged.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 14 March 2002:

quote.para: Has the Australian Greenhouse Office advised that it will be able to accurately report on emissions abatement compared to year 2004 forecast after all progress reports covering the 2000-2001 financial year are received; if so, (a) have all reports been received, (b) can the Australian Greenhouse Office now report on comparative emissions abatement and (c) will it make that data publicly available.

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr Kemp
talker.role: Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: All Greenhouse Challenge reports to date relate to member companies' year 2000 forecasts of the anticipated results of their abatement actions. No forecasts have been requested for year 2004.

Greenhouse Challenge members have the option to report on any 12 month cycle that fits with their other business requirements. As a result, some data relating to the 2000 calendar year forecast will be included in reports which predominately cover 2001, and some of these reports are only now becoming due. Only after all of these reports have been received will the Australian Greenhouse Office be able to accurately report on actual emissions abatement in 2000 compared to the 2000 aggregate forecast.
The answers to the honourable member's sub questions are as follows:
(a) No. As explained above, some data relating to year 2000 is still to be received.
(b) No. The Australian Greenhouse Office will not be able to report on comparative emissions abatement until all relevant data has been received, analysed and aggregated.
(c) Yes. Aggregated data will be made available when relevant data has been received, processed and analysed by the Australian Greenhouse Office.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 14 March 2002:

quote.para: (1) Of the 550 members of the Greenhouse Challenge were there 90 corporate progress reports overdue as at 4 June 2001, including 13 from large companies.
(2) How many reports are now overdue, and how many of those are from large companies.

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr Kemp
talker.role: Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Yes.

(2) As at 27 March 2002, Greenhouse Challenge membership totalled 719. Of these, 72 members had overdue progress reports, of which only 8 were from large companies. None of the 8 currently overdue reports from large companies were among those reported as overdue at 4 June 2001. All of those reports have been received. The Australian Greenhouse Office is continuing to work with all other members with overdue progress reports to overcome any difficulties and facilitate finalisation of their reports as soon as possible.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Greenhouse Office: Building Industry Grants
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 219)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 14 March 2002:

quote.para: Was the availability of Australian Greenhouse Office Grants to the building sector for voluntary initiatives ever publicly announced or the program's existence made known to the broader community.

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr Kemp
talker.role: Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: After extensive consultation with the building sector it was determined that the most effective strategy in addressing greenhouse gas emissions in buildings was through key market intermediaries such as peak industry bodies.

As a result, all relevant peak bodies in the building sector were informed of the availability of grants under the Voluntary Building Industry Initiatives Program (VBIIP) by way of extensive consultation and the provision of information on the program.
VBIIP grants were available only to peak bodies in the building sector. Since the grants were not offered to the public their availability was not publicly announced.

Once the grants were committed the recipients and details of their respective projects were made known to the broader community through a range of communications mechanisms, including industry journals, industry web sites, the Australian Greenhouse Office Newsletter `Greenhouse News' and the Australian Greenhouse Office web site www.greenhouse.gov.au.

question.para: Did a Senate Estimates response indicate that grant funds available under the National Reserve System Program, but unspent as at 1 July 2001 totalled $17.649m; if so, what sum has since been spent.

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: Yes, this information was provided in response to a question at Senate Estimates. Expenditure on grants under the National Reserve System Program in the period 1 July 2001 to 31 March 2002 was $11.752m.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 14 March 2002:

quote.para: (1) Was the application for Natural Heritage Trust funding in 2002 titled “Patchwork: Adopt a Patch (Stage 2) - Building Community Partnerships in Local Bushland” rejected by the former Minister in September 2001.
(2) Was the project rated seventh out of 95 projects submitted by the Tasmanian State Assessment Panel.
(3) How many projects from Tasmania were funded.
(4) Were projects ranked lower than 7th by the Assessment Panel funded.
(5) Has all money from this program been allocated.
(6) Was all the money spent.

(7) Did the project (a) involve primary students from no fewer than 62 schools, (b) attract involvement from the Tasmanian Education Department and Greening Australia (Tasmania) and (c) involve two schools that have won National Awards as a result of their Adopt a Patch work; if so, why did the Government think this project was not value for money.

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr Kemp
talker.role: Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Yes.

(2) Not all projects submitted by the State Minister for Commonwealth consideration were ranked. One hundred and sixty-four projects were submitted to Ministers Hill and Truss through the One Stop Shop for consideration following advice from the State Assessment Panel. Of the 164 projects, 95 were ranked. The “Adopt a Patch” proposal was ranked 7th out of the 95 ranked projects.
(3) 153 projects were funded from the One Stop Shop submission.
(4) Yes.
(5) The “Adopt a Patch” project was submitted for funding from the Bushcare Program. The funding from this program is fully allocated.
(6) The Commonwealth has provided $4,129,747 to Tasmania for approved projects. A further $1,580,751 is contracted to be paid in June 2002.

(7) (a) No. 53 schools (including primary school, high schools and colleges) have been funded over three years through the first “Adopt a Patch” project. The 2001-2002 “Patchwork; Adopt a Patch (Stage 2) - Building Community Partnerships in Local Bushland” project application indicated that a further 10 schools would be funded from Natural Heritage Trust funds.
(b) Yes. Greening Australia and the Department of Education were the project proponents.
(c) The project application indicates that one school had won a State landcare education award, and this school and one other were finalists in the Readers Digest Environment Award.

The Natural Heritage Trust primarily funds on-ground environmental action, particularly projects conducted as part of wider regional and national strategies that act to reverse damage done, protect what remains, and restore Australia's natural environment. While education and awareness activities are significant components of the Trust, school-based projects (where the primary aim is environmental education) are not a priority for the Trust, given the focus on local on-ground works. A January 2001 evaluation of the “Adopt a Patch” project indicated that the project was regarded “as an educational one first and foremost with on-ground outcomes secondary”, and that the “On-ground outcomes are not regarded by staff [educational staff] as being particularly good.”

The Commonwealth Government considered that the strategic value of on-ground activities by schools in the “Adopt a Patch” project was less than optimal. This was taken into account when assessing the “Adopt a Patch” project against Commonwealth strategic priorities, within funding available for Bushcare projects in Tasmania.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 14 March 2002:

question.para: (1) How many Migrant Resource Centres (MRCs) or MRC outposts are currently funded by the Government.
(2) How many of these centres were first approved for funding after March 1996.
(3) In respect of the new centres funded referred to in part (2), in which (a) location and (b) federal electoral division is each centre located.
(4) Have any centres had their funding withdrawn since March 1996; if so, in which (a) location and (b) electoral division did each centre previously operate.
(5) What specific criteria are used in assessing the need for MRCs to be established, or to remain, in particular locations.

talker.name: Hardgrave, Gary, MP
Mr Hardgrave
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Government currently funds 30 Migrant Resource Centres and 4 Migrant Service Agencies. Two of the Migrant Resource Centres operate outreach services.
(2) Eight centres were first approved for funding after March 1996.

(3) The Department does not collect data by electorate. Using information provided on the Australian Electoral Commission's website, a table providing the location and relevant electorate for the centres referred to in part (2) has, however, been prepared and is below. The electorate has been identified on the basis of the organisation's postcode. The service provision catchment area may extend across electoral boundaries.

(4) The Department has ceased funding two MRCs since March 1996. In both cases appropriate alternative services were established and service delivery in the area was not diminished. A table providing (a) location and (b) electoral division for each centre is provided in the table below.

(5) The establishment of a new MRC/MSA or the relocation of an existing MRC/MSA would be considered on a case by case basis. Factors that would be taken into consideration include: an identified need for settlement services not currently available in the relevant area; significant changes in the locations where new arrivals are settling; a shift in settlement patterns by existing migrant communities. Data from the ABS Census, community feedback and information from the Department's Settlement Database are also relevant sources of information in this process.
In the course of assessing the annual budget bids by MRCs/MSAs, the department considers a number of criteria, including:
changing demographics in relation to catchment areas of each MRC/MSA; and
identified settlement needs.
Part (2): MRCs/MSAs first approved for funding after March 1996
Part (3): MRC/MSA Location and Electorate
Part (4): MRCs/MSAs that had their funding withdrawn since March 1996

subdebateinfo.title: International Conference on Financing for Development and World Summit on Sustainable Development: Attendees
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 231)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 14 March 2002 :

quote.para: (1) What are the names and positions of the Australians who will attend the International Conference on Financing for Development and World Summit on Sustainable Development: Attendees to be held in Monterey, Mexico, between 18 and 22 March 2002.
(2) What are the names and positions of the Australians who will attend the World Summit on Sustainable Development to be held in Johannesburg between 26 August and 4 September 2002.

talker.name: Downer, Alexander, MP
Mr Downer
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows :

quote.para: (1) The names and positions of the members of the Australian delegation to the International Conference on Financing for Development and World Summit on Sustainable Development: Attendees are:
The Hon Chris Gallus MP, Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs.
Mr John Dauth, Ambassador to the United Nations.
Mr Graeme Wilson, Ambassador to Mexico.
Mr Rod Smith, Assistant Secretary , International Organisations Branch, DFAT.
Ms Frances Lisson, Acting Assistant Secretary, Trade Policy Issues and Industrials Branch, DFAT.
Dr Robert Glasser, Assistant Director General, Corporate Policy Branch, AusAID.
Mr Alan March, Director, Development Banks Section, AusAID.
Ms Tristen Slade, Departmental Liaison Officer, AusAID.
Ms Michelle Stone, Acting Manager, Development Banks Unit, Department of Treasury.
Mr Guy O'Brien, Second Secretary, Australian Mission to the UN, New York.
Ms Shampa Sinha, Second Secretary, Australian Embassy, Mexico City.
Mr Brett Parris, representative of the Australian Council for Overseas Aid.

(2) The agenda for the WSSD is not expected to be finalised until early June. A decision on the names and positions of the members of the Australian delegation to the Summit will be taken after that time.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 14 March 2002:

quote.para: (1) Is the Government aware of the 1993 US Congressional investigation, titled October Surprise Taskforce, into the veracity of claims made regarding the Iran-Contra affair.
(2) Is he aware of the conclusions reached by the Taskforce regarding the allegations and veracity of Mr Arie Ben-Menashe.
(3) What is the Australian Government's view of the allegations by Mr Ben-Menashe as to major money laundering into Western Australia a decade ago.
(4) Will the Government support the initiative of Senator Murray to bring Mr Ben-Menashe to Australia to testify to the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters.

talker.name: Downer, Alexander, MP
Mr Downer
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's questions are as follows:

quote.para: (1) The Government is aware of the report of the October Surprise Taskforce, established in 1992 to investigate issues related to the release of American hostages held in the US Embassy in Tehran in 1979. I am not aware of any direct connection between this report and the Iran-Contra affair, which refers to the sale of arms to Iran during the mid-1980s.
(2) See my answer above.
(3) This question is not within my portfolio responsibility.
(4) This question is not within my portfolio responsibility.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, Science and Training, upon notice, on 14 March 2002:

quote.para: (1) What sums were provided to (a) government and (b) non-government schools in (i) 2000 and (ii) 2001 in the postcode areas of (A) 3074, (B) 3075, (C) 3076, (D) 3082, (E) 3083 (F) 3087, (G) 3088, (H) 3089, (I) 3090, (J) 3091 and (K) 3752 and what was the (I) expenditure on, (II) location of, and (III) purpose of, each grant.
(2) Using the criteria referred in part (1), what are the allocations for 2002.

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
Dr Nelson
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Funding provided by the Department of Education, Science and Training is not allocated or and reported on the basis of postcodes or electorates.

(2) However, information on Capital Grant funding for government and non-government schools and General Recurrent Grants funding and Establishment Grant funding to non-government schools has been compiled on the basis of data available at the postcode level.
CAPITAL FUNDING (Non-Government Schools)

Commonwealth capital grants for schools are provided to improve educational outcomes by assisting in the provision of school facilities, particularly in ways that contribute most to raising the overall level of educational achievement of Australian school students.
Between 2000-02 only one non-government school in the above listed postcodes received Capital funding:

entry.para: Construction of: 2 technology rooms, 2 art and design rooms, offices, store and travel areas.

quote.para: CAPITAL FUNDING (Government Schools)
Between 2000-02 government schools in the above listed postcodes received the following Capital funding.
The allocation for the Capital Grants programme for non-government schools in Victoria for 2002 is $53,379,000. Not all this funding has yet been allocated.

entry.para: Construction of: general purpose classrooms and staff administration.
Construction of: general purpose classrooms, lecture room, staff administration, student lounge and locker space.
Construction of: general purpose classrooms and staff workspace.
