talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 20 March 2002:

quote.para: (1) What impact does the switch of new car buyers from passenger vehicles to the All Terrain Wagon Category vehicle potentially have on fuel consumption and the environment.

(2) Has the Government given any consideration to the impact on the environment of higher fuel consumption due to switching to All Terrain Wagon Category vehicles and passenger vehicles that are larger and more powerful.

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr Kemp
talker.role: Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) According to the Bureau of Transport and Regional Economics, as a proportion of new light vehicle sales, the All Terrain Wagons have increased from less than 3% in 1979 to nearly 15% by 2001, and the rising trend is expected to continue (BTRE 2002).

As this category comprises vehicles that are generally heavier, four-wheel driven and more powerful than their counterpart `passenger cars', the All Terrain Wagons have a higher fuel consumption compared to vehicles in the Passenger Cars category.

(2) The Government has in place a range of measures designed to help reduce the overall fuel consumption of the Australian passenger vehicle fleet and thereby reduce the greenhouse intensity and environmental impact of passenger vehicles, including All Terrain Wagons.

The Commonwealth enacted the Fuel Quality Standards Act 2000 to tighten vehicle emission standards and improve the quality of petrol and diesel. Mandatory fuel consumption labelling was introduced on 1 January 2001 for new passenger vehicles up to 2.7 tonnes gross vehicle mass and is being extended to cover heavier passenger vehicles, including All Terrain Wagons.

The Department of Transport and Regional Services together with the Australian Greenhouse Office is developing a `Green Vehicles' guide to inform consumers about both air quality and greenhouse issues.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 20 March 2002:

quote.para: (1) Further to the answer to part (1) of question No 166, is it a fact that (a) the Chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Authority (ABA), Professor David Flint, chaired the “Cash-for-Comment” inquiry involving the conduct of Radio 2UE broadcaster John Laws and (b) during the “Cash-for-Comment” inquiry, Professor Flint went on the Radio 2UE John Laws' program to argue the “No” case in the referendum on the Republic; if so, does Professor Flint's appearance on the Radio 2UE John Laws' program constitute a conflict of interest; if not, why not.
(2) Will he sack Professor Flint from the ABA; if not why not.

(3) Further to the answer to part (1) of question No 166; did the Government tell the people of Australia before the last Federal election that, in relation to its “commitment to reform Australia's media ownership rules”, the government would legislate to allow a media owner to own newspapers, television stations and radio stations in the one licence area; if so, is the Minister able to say when and where this was reported in the media; if not, why not.
(4) Does the Government believe that it has a mandate to legislate to allow a media owner to own newspapers, television stations and radio stations in the one licence area; if so, why.
(5) Is the existence of a diverse media crucial to the future of Australia's democracy; if not, why not.
(6) Is commercial media ownership in Australia dominated by the Murdoch family's News Limited and the Packer family's Publishing and Broadcasting Limited (PBL); if not, why not.

(7) How can diversity of media opinion in Australia be truly guaranteed if News Limited and PBL are allowed to own, in addition to their existing national and international media interests, newspapers, television stations and radio stations in the one licence area.

(8) Is the Minister aware of media research demonstrating that, in terms of access to news and information which affects the way people vote, most people still get such news and information from newspapers, television stations and radio stations.
(9) Does he still intend to legislate to allow News Limited and PBL to own newspapers, television stations and radio stations in the one licence area; if so, why.

(10) Further to his reply to question No. 133, would changes to foreign ownership laws potentially provide more competition to Australia's existing media owners and greater diversity of media opinion; if so, how; if not, why not.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
Mr McGauran
talker.role: Minister for Science

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) The Australian Broadcasting Authority (ABA) has provided the following advice:

(a) “The Chairman of the ABA, Professor David Flint chaired an investigation in to the commercial radio industry in 1999 from 15 July 1999 until 8 November 1999. The inquiry related to a number of radio stations, and began with Radio 2UE.

(b) “Professor Flint appeared on the John Laws programme on 1 November 1999, not to argue the “No” case in the referendum, but to exercise a right of reply to a statement by Mr Bob Hawke that Professor Flint was lying when he stated that were Australia to become republic, unanimous approval of all members of the Commonwealth would be required for Australia to remain in the organisation. The right of reply was exercised for the reason that it would be heard by precisely the same audience which had heard Mr Hawke's statement, thus mitigating the damage suffered by Professor Flint.

“In standing down from the inquiry on 8 November 1999, Professor Flint responded to concerns expressed about `apprehension of bias' and the threat of an action by the Communications Law Centre (not a party to the proceedings) to take the issue of `apprehension of bias' to the Federal Court. Professor Flint did not stand aside from the inquiry because of any issue relating to `conflict of interest', nor was this argued by the Communications Law Centre.

“After Professor Flint stood down from the inquiry, he immediately re-constituted the inquiry panel (in accordance with s. 193 of the BSA). Accordingly, the inquiry continued that day with only a minimal interruption and Professor Flint took no further part in the inquiry. Professor Flint also absented himself from all ABA discussion of the Panel's report, and from all meetings where the recommendations of the inquiry dealing with the condition on 2UE's licence were discussed.”
(2) No. Such action would not have been justified.

(3) The Government made an election commitment to reform Australia's anachronistic media ownership laws. As part of this commitment, the Government informed the Australian public that it supported a system of `exemptions' from existing cross media rules if specific conditions relating to the maintenance of diversity of opinion and information were met.
A press release announcing this election commitment was issued on 23 October 2001 and was covered extensively in the media.
(4) Yes, subject to certain existing and proposed regulatory requirements, because the Government made an election commitment to that effect.
(5) Yes.
(6) No. There are a number of media owners in Australia, including News Limited and PBL.

(7) Under the Broadcasting Services Amendment (Media Ownership) Bill 2002, the ABA may grant exemptions from existing cross-media rules provided that certain strict conditions are met. A primary objective of these conditions is to ensure that a diversity of opinion and information is maintained in Australian media. Any person or organisation seeking an exemption from cross-media rules will be required to demonstrate the existence of separate editorial policies; appropriate organisational charts; and separate editorial news management, news compilation processes and news gathering and interpretation capabilities.
(8) Yes.
(9) See answer to part (7) above.

(10) Yes. The removal of Australia's media-specific foreign ownership laws will provide more competition to Australia's existing media owners and greater diversity of media opinion by allowing, subject to the Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act 1975, for the entry of new organisations into the market.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 21 March 2002:

quote.para: (1) What estimates has his Department made of the economic and employment impact resulting from the US decision to impose a 30 per cent tariff on iron ore exports from WA to North-East Asia.
(2) What estimates has his Department made of the down-stream economic and employment impact on the fabrication and mining related supply industries in WA.
(3) What estimate has his Department made of the impact of greater global oversupply of steel on the iron ore industry in WA.

talker.name: Vaile, Mark, MP
Mr Vaile
talker.role: Minister for Trade

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows :

quote.para: (1) It is assumed that this question relates to the impact on the Western Australian iron ore industry of the US safeguard measure on steel, through its impact on the steel industries of North-East Asia, which import Australian ore.

As outlined by the Ministers for Trade, Industry, Tourism and Resources and Justice and Customs, following their summit with the steel industry on 19 March, the Government is concerned at the possible impact of the United States' import restrictions on Australia's upstream exports. The Government is maintaining regular contact with the steel industry and is monitoring closely developments in key markets to ensure that it is able to respond effectively, in concert with the Australian industry, to any major disruptions in ore and other commodity markets.

The precise impact of the United States' restrictions will depend on a range of factors, including the responses of other countries to the restrictions. Because those responses are not yet known, at this stage it is not possible to provide a firm estimate of the type referred to in the question. To put it in context, it is estimated that the United States' restrictions will result in approximately 5% of global steel exports being diverted from the United States market. Steel exporters in the European Union are likely to be most heavily affected by the restrictions. Both Japan and the Republic of Korea are significant exporters of steel to the United States and are also expected to experience some export losses. Whether or not these are translated into steelmaking reductions - and therefore reductions in demand for Australian ore - will depend in part on whether these countries can find alternative markets for their steel. In that context, it is a matter of concern to Australia that a number of countries, most notably the European Union, Malaysia and Mexico, have introduced their own import restrictions to address the risk of import surges into their markets. On 28 March I called on steel trading nations to show maximum restraint in responding to the US decision. Developments in China's steel production are also expected to have a significant bearing on developments in the market for ore and other commodities. At this stage, advice received by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade from the Department of Industry, Tourism and Resources and the Australian iron ore industry suggests that industry is confident of its capacity to address any challenges in the near term.

(2) For the reasons mentioned in the answer to (1) it is not possible to provide firm estimates at this stage. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is monitoring developments closely and in cooperation with other relevant agencies, including the Department of Industry, Tourism and Resources, the Department is aiming to develop as comprehensive a picture as possible of the likely impact on Australian interests. This information will be used as a basis for advice and recommendations to Ministers on appropriate policy responses, including actions to be pursued though the Ministerial Task Force on steel, which was established after the steel industry summit in March 2002.

(3) The extent of global oversupply of steel depends in large part on steel making capacity, the extent to which that capacity is being used and the level of global demand for steel. Latest estimates from the OECD indicate that between 124-128 million tones of steel-making capacity will be closed as the result of restructuring in the global industry between now and 2005. This amounts to about 11% of current global capacity, but the closures may not have a significant impact given that much of this capacity may already be idle. Global demand for steel depends most importantly on overall global economic growth, which is expected to strengthen over the course of this year. Given these variables, it is not yet clear that the global oversupply of steel will be significantly greater in the coming period. In addition, the factors mentioned in the answer to (1) mean that it is not possible to provide firm estimates of the type referred to in the question at this stage.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, Science and Training, upon notice, on 21 March 2002:

quote.para: (1) Does his Department publish each year a Job Guide reference book for students which provides descriptions of many different occupations and shows the education and training pathways to access these jobs.
(2) Prior to 2002, how has the Job Guide been distributed.
(3) Has each Year 10 student been issued with a Job Guide.
(4) Has the distribution changed for the 2002 Job Guide.
(5) Will only a set number of books and CD-ROM versions of the Job Guide be distributed to each school.

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
Dr Nelson
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The Department publishes the Job Guide each year. It is provided on the Internet, on CD ROM and as a State/Territory book.

(2) Prior to 2002, each school received one copy for each Year 10 student, a resource set of 20 books and a set of floppy disks. It has been available on the Internet for several years. Job Guide was also distributed to, amongst others, Centrelink, public, university and TAFE libraries, correctional institutions and DEST programme providers.
(3) By mid May 2002 each school should have received a Job Guide for every Year 10 student.
(4) Job Guide distribution to schools for 2002 will be:
· Job Guide on the Internet;
· 10 CD ROMS for each school as resource sets; and
· sufficient books for each Year 10 student.
Job Guide will also be distributed to, amongst others, Centrelink, public, university and TAFE libraries, correctional institutions and DEST programme providers.
(5) See answer to 4 above.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 21 March 2002:

quote.para: (1) How many Special Purpose visas have been granted to the crew of ships holding single voyage permits in (a) 1996, (b) 1997, (c) 1998, (d) 1999, (e) 2000, (f) 2001 and (g) 2002 to date.
(2) How many Special Purpose visas have been granted to the crew of ships holding continuous voyage permits in (a) 1996, (b) 1997, (c) 1998, (d) 1999, (e) 2000, (f) 2001 and (g) 2002 to date.
(3) Are these visas issued automatically to the crew of ships issued with (a) a single voyage permit and (b) continuous voyage permits.
(4) What procedure is undertaken by his Department in issuing Special Purpose visas to ship crews.

(5) What background checks are made on individual crew members issued Special Purpose visas to ensure they are not members of (a) international organised crime networks and (b) suspected international terrorist organisations.
(6) Have there been any instances where Special Purpose visas have been revoked due to a crew member being involved in (a) organised crime or (b) international terrorism.
(7) Does his Department keep records of the names and other details of all the crew members issued with Special Purpose visas.
(8) In light of the increased danger of a terrorist attack on Australia has he made any changes to the issuing of Special Purpose visas to visiting seafarers.

(9) In relation to the issuing of Special Purpose visas for the crew of ships with continuous voyage permits what is (a) the average life of visas issued and (b) the longest period of time a foreign seafarer has worked in Australian waters on a Special Purpose visa.

(10) Do foreign seafarers issued with a Special Purpose visa on ships holding a continuous voyage permit fall under the residency requirements of paragraph 6(1)(a) of he Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 and pay tax when they work in Australian waters for over six months.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Special Purpose Visas (SPV's) come into effect through operation of law. No applications are required and no grants are recorded. “Single Voyage Permits” are issued to ships by the Department of Transport and Regional Services and details of the crew on those ships are held by the Australian Customs Service (ACS), which undertakes the seaport processing function on behalf of the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA).
(2) Refer to (1) above. The same information applies to “Continuing Voyage Permits”.

(3) Special Purpose Visas come into effect for listed crew when their ship, if it is engaged in commercial trade or carriage of passengers, enters Australia at a proclaimed port. Some such ships are subsequently issued with a “Single” or “Continuing Voyage Permit” by the Department of Transport and Regional Services. In general, the crew of such ships will already hold SPV's by virtue of their being on the crew list.

(4) The visas come into effect through operation of law. Provided a crewmember is listed on a ship engaged in commercial trade or carriage of passengers that enters Australia at a proclaimed port, the crewmember will be taken to hold a Special Purpose Visa.

(5) At least 48 hours before arriving in Australia crew lists are transmitted to the Australian Customs Service, which undertakes alert checking against ACS and DIMIA alert lists. If a crewmember is recorded on an alert list, DIMIA is advised and a declaration can be made to the effect that the crewmembers' entry is undesirable. If such a declaration is made, a SPV does not come into effect and the crewmember is confined on board the ship during its stay in Australian waters.
(6) There are no instances recorded of a Special Purpose Visa being revoked because of connections with organised crime or international terrorism.

(7) ACS holds copies of crew lists for a period of seven years and these are available to DIMIA if required. Details of crewmembers who sign off and on ships at Australian ports are copied to DIMIA to be recorded on DIMIA systems as arriving or departing.

(8) Yes, a number of proposed changes are currently before Parliament. The Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2002 seeks to provide power to immediately detain a crewmember whose SPV has been ceased because their entry is undesirable. The Border Security Legislation Amendment Bill 2002 seeks to amend the Migration Act 1958 to require airline and ship operators to provide advance passenger and crew information to DIMIA.

(9) Because of the way Special Purpose Visas operate it is not possible to provide an average visa life. Most ships visit Australia only briefly as part of an international voyage and the crew of such ships will hold Special Purpose Visas. Some ships on international voyages are subsequently granted “Single Voyage Permits” and some are granted “Continuing Voyage Permits”, both of which are limited by time. Special Purpose Visas held by crew on ships covered by these permits will be in effect for a longer period.
(10) This is a matter on which it would be best for the Commissioner of Taxation to advise.

subdebateinfo.title: Prospect Electorate: Family Tax and Child-Care Benefit
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 277)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Children and Youth Services, upon notice, on 21 March 2002:

quote.para: (1) Has he sent letters to constituents in the electoral division of Prospect requesting repayments of the family tax and child care benefit; if so, how many letters have been sent.
(2) What is the average overpayment which has been made to families in the electoral division of Prospect.
(3) What time frame do individuals have to pay back their overpayments.

talker.name: Anthony, Larry, MP
Mr Anthony
talker.role: Minister for Children and Youth Affairs

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The only information available is the number of customers in your electorate who were overpaid as at 31 January 2002. For the electoral division of Prospect 3,606 family tax benefit customers and 735 child care benefit customers received notification that they incurred a debt as a result of the income reconciliation process. However, only customers who incurred a debt over $1,000 would need to repay.

(2) The average overpayment in the electoral division of Prospect, for family tax benefit is $934 and $280 for child care benefit. To assist families adjust to the new tax system, the government introduced the transitional measure that resulted in the first $1,000 of each debt being waived therefore many of these customers will not have to repay.
(3) Customers were given a range of flexible repayment options that allowed them to tailor the recovery to suit their individual circumstances.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Children and Youth Services, upon notice, on 21 March 2002:

quote.para: (1) Was evidence given to a Senate estimates committee on 21 February 2002 that tens of millions of dollars have been over paid to child care services; if so, (a) which child care services in the electoral division of Prospect were overpaid and (b) what sum will each child care service in the electoral division of Prospect be requested to repay.
(2) What is the procedure for debt recovery if a child care provider is unable to repay its overpayment.

talker.name: Anthony, Larry, MP
Mr Anthony
talker.role: Minister for Children and Youth Affairs

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) A listing of all child care service in the electorate of Prospect and their Childcare Assistance overpayment amounts finalised as at 10 April 2002 are outlined below.

entry.para: GREYSTANES UNITING CHURCH CHILD CARE CENTRE
CUDDLY BEAR PRE-SCHOOL LONG DAY CARE
THE PARKS OCCASIONAL CHILD CARE CENTRE
FAIRFIELD CITY WEST AFTER SCHOOL CARE
FAIRFIELD CITY WEST BEFORE SCHOOL CARE
OUR LADY OF THE ROSARY BEFORE SCHOOL CARE
OUR LADY OF THE ROSARY AFTER SCHOOL CARE
OUR LADY OF THE ROSARY VACATION CARE
FAIRFIELD HEALTH SERVICE CHILD CARE CENTRE

quote.para: NYF = Not Yet Finalised

(2) Services have always received payments in advance. The Childcare Assistance over-advances are the result of the on-going advance/acquit cycle which ensures services have enough money up front to operate. Services have always been required to reconcile payments with actual usage and have benefited from the use of this money for some time.

Services have the option to either repay the Childcare Assistance overpayment in full within one month of receiving their CA finalisation letter. Alternatively, they may choose to have the overpayments deducted from future monthly Child Care Benefit advances at a maximum rate of 25%. Finalisation letters also advise services that they may re-negotiate the recovery rate to a lower percentage if repayment is likely to cause severe financial hardship.
Finalisation letters to services provide two contact numbers - one to discuss the actual Childcare Assistance overpayment, the other to discuss/re-negotiate repayment arrangements.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Defence Force: Support to the United States of America
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 279)

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 21 March 2002:

quote.para: (1) Has the Prime Minister committed any members of the Australian Defence Force to be deployed in assisting the US in its proposed war against Iraq or any of the other countries considered to be harbouring terrorists.
(2) Did the Prime Minister pledge further assistance to the US in its war against terrorism in return for the US decision to remove tariffs from 85 per cent of Australia's steel exports.

talker.name: Howard, John, MP
Mr Howard
talker.role: Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) No, with the exception of the commitment of forces publicly announced in relation to operations in Afghanistan.

subdebateinfo.title: New South Wales Bushfires: Volunteer Firefighters
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 282)

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 21 March 2002:

quote.para: (1) Is he aware that following the Sydney bushfires of 1994 at least 10 cases of SES volunteers in logistical and other support roles were provided with financial assistance under the scheme initiated by then Prime Minister Keating and then Premier Fahey to compensate volunteer fire fighters for loss of income.

(2) In light of his statement to Premier Carr that he is strictly following the agreement struck between their respective predecessors in 1994, why has he decided not to extend assistance to all volunteers, fire-fighters, logistics and support alike, for loss of income as a result of the NSW Christmas 2001- 2002 bushfire emergency.

(3) How does he explain this contradiction in the treatment of volunteers from the 1994 bushfires compared with volunteers in the 2001-02 bushfire emergency, when the same guidelines are apparently being applied in relation to the granting of financial assistance for loss of income.

talker.name: Howard, John, MP
Mr Howard
talker.role: Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) I am advised by my department that, for the period from 3 January to 14 January 1994, the NSW bushfires were declared a `major disaster' under the Social Security Act 1991. According to the terms of the Act, Disaster Relief Payments (DRP) were therefore available to people who suffered severe damage to their principal residence, and/or a significant interruption to their normal source of income as a result of the disaster. Volunteer firefighters who lost income while firefighting for seven days or more were eligible for DRP under the second criterion. The then government decided that, in addition to DRP, it would make available ex gratia payments to volunteer firefighters who lost income while firefighting for up to seven days. To be eligible for these payments, claimants had to demonstrate that they were members of recognised volunteer firefighting services, that they had been involved in fighting the bushfires, and that they had lost income because of this involvement. State Emergency Service (SES) volunteers were not eligible for the ex gratia payments targeted at firefighters. However, if they met either of the criteria for the DRP they would have been eligible, like all members of the public, for the DRP. It is possible that a number of SES volunteers may have been paid the DRP in this way in 1994.

(2) The 2001-02 NSW bushfires did not meet the criteria of a `major disaster' according to the Social Security Act 1991. This meant that the DRP was not paid. However, following the precedent set by the policy of the government in 1994, the current government has made ex gratia payments available to volunteer firefighters who lost income while fighting the bushfires. Extending eligibility for the ex gratia payments beyond volunteer firefighters, would go beyond the precedent established in 1994.

(3) There is no contradiction between the treatment of volunteers during the 1994 bushfires compared with volunteers during the 2001-02 bushfires. In 1994, the government offered ex gratia payments specifically to volunteer firefighters who lost income while fighting the fires, quite separate from the payments made under the DRP arrangements. In 2001-02, the government has similarly offered ex gratia payments specifically to volunteer firefighters who lost income while firefighting.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 21 March 2002:

quote.para: (1) Did the Minister see an article titled “MPs rebel over media shake-up” by Aaron Patrick on page 1 of The Australian Financial Review, dated 20 March 2002.

(2) In view of the apparent disquiet by ten coalition members over the proposed changes to Australia's cross-media and foreign ownership laws as revealed by Mr Patrick, will the Minister refer the draft legislation to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Communications, Information Technology and the Arts for its consideration, review and recommendation to the Parliament; if not, why not.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
Mr McGauran
talker.role: Minister for Science

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) Yes.

(2) On 21 March 2002 the Broadcasting Services Amendment (Media Ownership) Bill was referred to the Senate Environment, Communications, Information Technology and the Arts Legislation Committee for inquiry and report.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 21 March 2002:

question.para: (1) How many firms are currently approved for (a) standard business sponsorships and (b) pre-qualified business sponsorship for the purposes of temporary long-stay business entrants in respect of the (i) construction industry, (ii) finance and insurance industry, and (iii) retail trade industry.

(2) How many long-stay business visas (subclass 457) were issued in (a) 2000-2001 and (b) 2001-2002 to date in respect of the (i) construction industry, (ii) finance and insurance industry, and (iii) retail trade industry.

(3) Are sponsors required to comply with Australian industrial relations laws, levels of remuneration and conditions of employment (including superannuation contributions) and to deduct appropriate income tax instalments.

(4) If an individual or organisation believes that a business sponsor is not meeting its obligations, as referred to in part (3), what is the process for submitting a complaint to his Department and what investigations does his Department conduct as a result.
(5) How many alleged breaches of sponsorship obligations did his Department investigate in 2000-2001 and what was the outcome of these investigations.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The table below provides the number of pre-qualified (PQBS) and standard (SBS) business sponsorships approved for these three industries in 2000-01 and the first six months of 2001-02. The PQBS approval is for two years. The SBS approval is for one year, or until the positions have been approved.

(2) Occupations of subclass 457 visa holders are based on data collected from nomination applications completed by the Australian employer. Every (primary) subclass 457 visa applicant must have an approved nomination before they can be granted a visa. The occupations for nominations approved indicates the number of visas granted in the period for the occupations requested. These are provided in the following table:
*Note: Based on nomination approvals during the period.

(3) All Australian employers sponsoring overseas employees are required to abide by Australian laws applicable to Australian employees. Conditions of employment are set out in the relevant state or federal legislation, state or federal award, industry sector award, collective agreement or Australian Workplace Agreement under which an employee is covered. Temporary residents employed under an award or an agreement are subject to the conditions of that award or agreement.

Australian sponsors are required to register all overseas employees sponsored under the 457 visa subclass in accordance with Australian superannuation laws and make the appropriate superannuation deductions and payments.

All employees in Australia are subject to Australian taxation legislation. An assessment of the tax status of temporary residents is made by the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) under their Residency Tests. Sponsors must sign an undertaking to accept responsibility for obligations to the Commonwealth for sponsored persons, including ensuring that tax instalments are deducted from salary or wages.

(4) If individuals believe employers are not complying with Australian laws, they can contact the relevant State or Commonwealth authority responsible for the enforcement of the particular legislation.

If individuals or organisations believe that a sponsoring company is breaching its sponsorship obligations, they can also bring those concerns to the attention of the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) Business Centre. DIMIA officers pass information to the appropriate enforcement authority for investigation. DIMIA will investigate breaches of the Migration Act and Regulations.
(5) The table below provides information concerning 14 allegations of exploitation of subclass 457 visa holders investigated by my Department in 2000-01.

para.inline: SUMMARY OF CASES OF ALLEGED EXPLOITATION INVOLVING 457 VISA HOLDERS 2000/01

entry.para: Allegation that employer/subcontractor had assaulted a Korean tiler.

Inquiries into this matter were made with the police. Assault is a criminal matter outside DIMIA portfolio responsibility. However, latest advice from the police is that no outcome has yet been reached. The company involved continues to be monitored closely including site visits to ensure no breaches of immigration rules or undertakings occur.

Sri Lankan chef claimed to have been exploited by employer: worked 51 hours per week but only paid for 38, payment below the award rate ($546 net per week), employer did not meet full cost of medical insurance.

Interview conducted at new place of employment. Employer listed on departmental systems as client of concern but has no current sponsorship. The chef has ceased employment with the sponsor and there are no other visa holders sponsored by the company. Appropriate notations made to departmental systems to ensure any future applications are closely vetted in light of allegations.
Allegation that Indonesian and Hong Kong housekeeping staff were being employed at below award rates.

Department contacted hotel management and referred details to DEWR for advice on whether the employer was in breach of the relevant award. DEWR confirmed the employer was in breach. On 7 June 2001 the Hotel made an undertaking to employ and pay visa holders at the correct level (retrospectively), to meet their obligations. The Hotel also undertook to put in place procedures to ensure future sponsored employees would be paid at appropriate Australian award rate. Monitoring of company is ongoing.
Employer of 8 temple workers had employed workers in breach of relevant award, Australian conditions of employment and OH&S legislation. Workers were housed in sub-standard accommodation.

Interviews held with workers and employer. Details referred to NSW DIR and ATO. Letter sent to employer asking why sponsorship standing should not be revoked. Agreement has been reached between parties and all workers have now departed Australia. Site visited by DIMIA compliance officers on 27 March 2002 to ensure no illegal workers on site. Officers confirmed visa and immigration conditions being adhered to by workers and sponsor at this time. Close monitoring is continuing.
In November 2000 a hairdresser complained of being exploited re wages. He was not prepared to make a formal complaint and left A/a shortly afterwards.
Sponsor has been noted on departmental systems in case of further sponsorships. No further applications have been lodged.
Allegation received from 4 Indian chefs that they had been paid less than agreed salary and had been threatened and intimidated by employer. Employer also alleged to have held passports of workers.

Interviews held with chefs and sponsor. Sponsor asked to demonstrate that he met sponsorship undertakings. Details referred to ATO and Qld Dept of Industrial Relations. Employer sought to sponsor 4 new chefs. The applications were refused as had not provided satisfactory documentation in regard to remuneration, tax and superannuation for prospective employees. Restaurant subsequently closed.
Chef applying to change employer made significant allegations against his previous employer in Sydney.

Matter has been investigated. Details of allegations referred where appropriate to relevant agencies. Site visit made to business premises to assess first hand remuneration records and other conditions of work. After lengthy enquiries a new sponsorship has been approved. However, company is being monitored closely to ensure all obligations and undertakings are met.
Malaysian chef alleged exploitation by his sponsor.
Matter has been investigated. No further action taken against employer. However, company activities are being closely monitored.
Chef stated he was overworked, underpaid, medical treatment not provided, charged an “immigration bond” by the employer.
Details of alleged bond referred to SA police who are investigating. A change of employer application for the visa holder to remain in Australia has been approved.
General allegation of underpayment/adverse employment conditions.
Matter resolved by employees departing Australia or changing employer. Details of employer recorded on departmental systems as “Client of Concern”.
General allegation of underpayment/adverse employment conditions.
Matter resolved by employees departing Australia or changing employer. Details of employer recorded on departmental systems in case further applications lodged.
General allegation of underpayment/adverse employment conditions.
Matter resolved by employees departing Australia or changing employer. Details of employer recorded on departmental systems in case further applications lodged.
Allegation that the company was not paying the award rate.

Site visit was undertaken in September 2000 with a member of CFMEU . Unable to substantiate claims at the time. A further site visit was undertaken in March 2001 and were informed that the work was completed in December 2000 and the workers had departed Australia. No further action required
Allegation that workers at a temple site may be working for below award wages.
Departmental officers visited the site on 6 March 2001 and spoke to management and workers. The workers indicated that they were satisfied with their pay and conditions.
